set.p: The scene is laid in Cairo , in the house and garden of the British Consular Agent .

div.head: ACT I

stage.stage: SCENE : The morning-room in the Consular Agent 's house at Cairo . The windows are Arabic in character and so are the architraves of the doors , but otherwise it is an English room , airy and spacious . The furniture is lacquer and Chippendale , there are cool chintzes on the chairs and sofas , cut roses in glass vases , and growing azaleas in pots ; but here and there an Eastern antiquity , a helmet and a coat of mail , a piece of woodwork , reminds one of the Mussulman conquest of Egypt ; while an ancient god in porphyry , graven images in blue pottery , blue bowls , recall an older civilisation still .

When the curtain rises the room is empty , the blinds are down so as to keep out the heat , and it is dim and mysterious . A SERVANT comes in , a dark-skinned native in the gorgeous uniform , red and gold , of the Consular Agent 's establishment , and draws the blinds . Through the windows is seen the garden with palm-trees , oranges and lemons , tropical plants with giant leaves ; and beyond , the radiant blue of the sky . In the distance is heard the plaintive , guttural wailing of an Arab song . A GARDENER in a pale blue gaberdine passes with a basket on his arm .

sp.speaker: SERVANT
sp.p: Es-salam ‘ alekumPeace be with you

lg.l: U'alekum eshYpppHeNSalam warahmet Allah wa barakata
lg.stage: And with you be peace and God 's mercy and blessing

div.stage: The SERVANT goes out . The GARDENER stops for a moment to nail back a straggling creeper and then goes on his way . The door is opened . MRS. APPLEBY comes in with ANNE ETHERIDGE and they are followed immediately by VIOLET . ANNE is a woman of forty , but handsome still , very pleasant and sympathetic ; she is a woman of the world , tactful and self-controlled . She is dressed in light , summery things . MRS. APPLEBY is an elderly , homely woman , soberly but not inexpensively dressed . The wife of a North-country manufacturer , she spends a good deal of money on rather dowdy clothes . VIOLET is a very pretty young woman of twenty . She looks very fresh and English in her muslin frock ; there is something spring-like and virginal in her appearance , and her manner of dress is romantic rather than modish . She suggests a lady in a Gainsborough portrait rather than a drawing in a paper of Paris fashions . Luncheon is just finished and when they come in the women leave the door open for the men to follow .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: How cool it is in here ! This is n't the room we were in before lunch ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: No . They keep the windows closed and the blinds drawn all the morning so that it 's beautifully cool when one comes in .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I suppose we sha n't feel the heat so much when we 've been here a few days .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh , but this is nothing to what you 'll get in Upper Egypt .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: As she enters .Is Mrs. Appleby complaining of the heat ? I love it .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Dear Violet , wait till May comes and June . You do n't know how exhausting it gets .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm looking forward to it . I think in some past life I must have been a lizard .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I dare say the first year you wo n't feel it . I have a brother settled in Canada , and he says the first year people come out from England they do n't feel the cold anything like what they do later on .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 've spent a good many winters here , and I always make a point of getting away by the fifteenth of March .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , are you staying as late as that ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Good gracious , no . You make Lady Little 's heart positively sink .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Nonsense , Anne , you know we want you to stay as long as ever you can .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I used to have an apartment in Cairo , but I 've given it up now and Lady Little asked me to come and stay at the Agency while I was getting everything settled .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , then you knew Sir Arthur before he married ?

lg.l: Oh , yes , he 's one of my oldest friends . I can n't help thinking Lady
Little must have great sweetness of character to put up with me .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Or you must be a perfect miracle of tact , darling .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: My belief is , it 's a little of both .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: When Arthur came to see me one day last July and told me he was going to marry the most wonderful girl in the world , of course I thought good-bye . A man thinks he can keep his bachelor friendships , but he never does .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: His wife generally sees to that .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Well , I think it 's nonsense , especially with a man like Arthur who 'd been a bachelor so long and naturally had his life laid out before ever I came into it . And besides , I 'm devoted to Anne .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It 's dear of you to say so .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I came here as an absolute stranger . And after all , I was n't very old , was I ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Nineteen ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , no , I was older than that . I was nearly twenty .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Smiling .Good gracious !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It was rather alarming to find oneself on a sudden the wife of a man in Arthur 's position . I was dreadfully self-conscious ; I felt that everybody 's eyes were upon me . And you do n't know how easy it is to make mistakes in a country that 's half Eastern and half European .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: To say nothing of having to deal with the representatives of half a dozen Great Powers all outrageously susceptible .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And , you know , there was the feeling that the smallest false step might do the greatest harm to Arthur and his work here . I had only just left the schoolroom and I found myself almost a political personage . If it had n't been for Anne I should have made a dreadful mess of things .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh , I do n't think that . You had two assets which would have made people excuse a great deal of inexperience , your grace and your beauty .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You say very nice things to me , Anne .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Your marriage was so romantic , I can n't see how anyone could help feeling very kindly towards you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: There 's not much room for romance in the heart of the wife of one of the Agents of the foreign Powers when she thinks she has n't been given her proper place at a dinner party .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I remember wondering at the time whether you were n't a little overcome by all the excitement caused by your marriage .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I was excited too , you know .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Everyone had always looked upon Sir Arthur as a confirmed bachelor . It was thought he cared for nothing but his work . He 's had a wonderful career , has n't he ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: The Prime Minister told me he was the most competent man he 'd ever met .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 've always thought he must be a comfort to any Government . Whenever anyone has made a hash of things he 's been sent to put them straight .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Well , he always has .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Mr. Appleby was saying only this morning he was the last man one would expect to marry in haste .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Let 's hope he wo n't repent at leisure .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Smiling .Mrs. Appleby is dying to know all about it , Violet .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm an old woman , Lady Little .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Gaily .Well , I met Arthur at a week-end party . He 'd come home on leave and all sorts of important people had been asked to meet him . I was frightened out of my life . The duchesses had strawberry leaves hanging all over them and they looked at me down their noses . And the Cabinet Ministers ’ wives had protruding teeth and they looked at me up their noses .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: What nonsense you talk , Violet !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I was expecting to be terrified of Arthur . After all , I knew he was a great man . But you know , I was n't a bit . He was inclined to be rather fatherly at first , so I cheeked him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I can imagine his surprise . No one had done that for twenty years .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: When you know Arthur at all well you discover that when he wants anything he does n't hesitate to ask for it . He told our hostess that he wanted me to sit next to him at dinner . That did n't suit her at all , but she did n't like to say no . Somehow people do n't say no to Arthur . The Cabinet Ministers ’ wives looked more like camels than ever , and by Sunday evening , my dear , the duchesses ’ strawberry leaves began to curl and crackle .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Your poor hostess , I feel for her . To have got hold of a real lion for your party and then have him refuse to bother himself with anybody but a chit of a girl whom you 'd asked just to make an even number !

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: He just fell in love with you at first sight ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: That 's what he says now .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Did you know ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I thought it looked very like it , you know , only it was so improbable . Then came an invitation from a woman I only just knew for the next week-end , and she said Arthur would be there . Then my heart really did begin to go pit-a-pat . I took the letter in to my sister and sat on her bed and we talked it over . “ Does he mean to propose to me , ” I said , “ or does he not ? ” And my sister said : “ I can n't imagine what he sees in you . Will you accept him if he does ? ” she asked . “ Oh , no , ” I said . “ Good heavens , why he 's twenty years older than I am ! ” But of course I meant to all the time . I should n't have cared if he was a hundred , he was the most wonderful man I 'd ever known .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: And did he propose to you that week-end , when he 'd practically only seen you once before ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I got down in the afternoon and he was there already . As soon as I swallowed a cup of tea he said : “ Come out for a walk . ” Well , I 'd have loved a second cup , but I did n't like to say so , so I went . But we had a second tea in a cottage half an hour later , and we were engaged then .

div.stage: APPLEBY comes in with OSMAN PASHA . MR. APPLEBY is a self-made man who has entered Parliament ; he is about sixty , grey-bearded , rather short and stout , with some accent in his speech , shrewd , simple and good-natured . He wears a blue serge suit . OSMAN PASHA is a swarthy , bearded Oriental , obese , elderly but dignified ; he wears the official frock-coat of the Khedivial service and a tarbush .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Sir Arthur is coming in one moment . He is talking to one of his secretaries .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Really , it 's too bad of them not to leave him alone even when he 's snatching a mouthful of food .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Vous permettez que j'apporte ma cigarette , chere Madame .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Of course . Come and sit here , Pasha .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I wanted to tell his Excellency how interested I am in his proposal to found a technical college in Cairo , but I can n't speak French .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , but his Excellency understands English perfectly , and I believe really he talks it as well as I do , only he wo n't .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Madame , je ne comprends l'anglais que quand vous le parlez , et tout galant homme sait ce que dit une jolie femme .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Translating for the APPLEBYS .He says he only understands English when Lady Little speaks it , and every nice man understands what a pretty woman says .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No one pays me such charming compliments as you do . You know I 'm learning Arabic .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: C'est une bien belle langue , et vous , madame , vous avez autant d'intelligence que de beaute .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I have a Copt who comes to me every day . And I practise a little with your brother , Anne .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: To MRS. APPLEBY .My brother is one of Sir Arthur 's secretaries . I expect it was he that Mr. Appleby left with Sir Arthur .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If it is I shall scold him . He knows quite well that he has no right to come and bother Arthur when he 's in the bosom of his family . But they say he 's a wonderful Arabic scholar .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Vous parlez de M. Parry ? Je n'ai jamais connu un Anglais qui avait une telle facilite .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: He says he 's never known an Englishman who speaks so well as Ronny .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's a fearfully difficult language . Sometimes my head seems to get tied up in knots .

div.stage: Two SAISES come in , one with a salver on which are coffee cups and the other bearing a small tray on which is a silver vessel containing Turkish coffee . They go round giving coffee to the various people , then wait in silence . When SIR ARTHUR comes in they give him his coffee and go out .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It 's wonderful of you to persevere .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , you know , Ronny 's very encouraging . He says I 'm really getting on . I want so badly to be able to talk . You can n't think how enthusiastic I am about Egypt . I love it .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Pas plus que l'Egypte vous aime , Madame .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: When we landed at Alexandria and I saw that blue sky and that coloured , gesticulating crowd , my heart leapt . I knew I was going to be happy . And every day I 've loved Egypt more . I love its antiquities , I love the desert and the streets of Cairo and those dear little villages by the Nile . I never knew there was such beauty in the world . I thought you only read of romance in books ; I did n't know there was a country where it sat by the side of a well under the palm-trees , as though it were at home .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Vous etes charmante , madame . C'est un bien beau pays . Il n'a besoin que d'une chose pour qu'on puisse y vivre .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Translating .It 's a beautiful country . It only wants one thing to make it livable . And what is that , your Excellency ?

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: La liberte .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Liberty ?

div.stage: ARTHUR has come in when first VIOLET begins to speak of Egypt and he listens to her enthusiasm with an indulgent smile . At the Pasha 's remark he comes forward . ARTHUR LITTLE is a man of forty-five , alert , young in manner , very intelligent , with the urbanity , self-assurance , tact , and resourcefulness of the experienced diplomatist . Nothing escapes him , but he does not often show how much he notices .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Egypt has the liberty to do well , your Excellency . Does it need the liberty to do ill before it loses the inclination to do it ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: To MRS. APPLEBY .I hope you do n't mind Turkish coffee ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , no , I like it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm so glad . I think it perfectly delicious .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You have in my wife an enthusiastic admirer of this country , Pasha .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: J'en suis ravi .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 've told Ronny to come in and have a cup of coffee .To ANNE .I thought you 'd like to say how d'you do to him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Are you very busy to-day ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: We 're always busy . Is n't that so , Excellency ?

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: En effet , et je vous demanderai permission de me retirer . Mon bureau m'appelle .

div.stage: He gets up and shakes hands with VIOLET .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It was charming of you to come .

sp.speaker: OSMAN PASHA
sp.p: Mon Dieu , madame , c'est moi qui vous remercie de m'avoir donne l'occasion de saluer votre grace et votre beaute .

div.stage: He bows to the rest of the company . ARTHUR leads him towards the door and he goes out .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You take all these compliments without turning a hair , Violet .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Coming back .You know , that 's a wonderful old man . He 's so well-bred , he has such exquisite manners , it 's hard to realise that if it were possible he would have us all massacred to-morrow .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I remember there was a certain uneasiness in England when you recommended that he should be made Minister of Education .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: They do n't always understand local conditions in England . Osman is a Moslem of the old school . He has a bitter hatred of the English . In course of years he has come to accept the inevitable , but he 's not resigned to it . He never loses sight of his aim .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: And that is ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why , bless you , to drive the English into the sea . But he 's a clever old rascal , and he sees that one of the first things that must be done is to educate the Egyptians . Well , we want to educate them too . I had all sorts of reforms in mind which I would never have got the strict Mohammedans to accept if they had n't been brought forward by a man whose patriotism they believe in and whose orthodoxy is beyond suspicion .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Do n't you find it embarrassing to work with a man you distrust ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't distrust him . I have a certain admiration for him , and I bear him no grudge at all because at the bottom of his heart he simply loathes me .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I do n't see why he should do that .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I was in Egypt for three years when I was quite a young man . I was very small fry then , but I came into collision with Osman and he tried to poison me . I was very ill for two months , and he 's never forgiven me because I recovered .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: What a scoundrel !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: He would be a little out of place in a Nonconformist community . In the good old days of Ismael he had one of his wives beaten to death and thrown into the Nile .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: But is it right to give high office to a man of that character ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: They were the manners and customs of the times .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: But he tried to kill you . Do n't you bear him any ill will ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't think it was very friendly , you know , but after all no statesman can afford to pay attention to his private feelings . His duty is to find the round peg for the round hole and put him in .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why does he come here ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: He has a very great and respectful admiration for Violet . She chaffs him , if you please , and the old man adores her . I think she 's done more to reconcile him to the British occupation than all our diplomacy .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: It must be wonderful to have power in a country like this .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Power ? Oh , I have n't that . But it makes me so proud to think I can be of any use at all . I only wish I had the chance to do more . Since I 've been here I 've grown very patriotic .

div.stage: RONALD PARRY comes in . He is a young man , very good-looking , fresh and pleasant , with a peculiar charm of manner .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Ah , here is Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Am I too late for my cup of coffee ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , it will be brought to you at once .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Shaking hands with VIOLET .Good morning .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: This is Mr. Parry . Mr. and Mrs. Appleby .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: How d'you do ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Now , Ronny , do n't put on your Foreign Office manner . Mr. and Mrs. Appleby are very nice people .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm glad you think that , Sir Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Well , when you left your cards with a soup ticket from the F. O . my heart sank .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: There , my dear , I told you he would n't want to be bothered with us .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You see , I expected a pompous couple who knew all about everything and were going to tell me exactly how Egypt ought to be governed . A Member of Parliament does n't inspire confidence in the worried bosom of a Government official .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't know if you think you 're putting Mr. and Mrs. Appleby at their ease , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , but I should n't say this if I had n't been most agreeably disappointed .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I never forget the days when Mr. Appleby used to light the kitchen fire himself and I used to do the week 's washing every Monday morning . I do n't think we 've changed much since then , either of us .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I know , and I 'm really grateful to the Foreign Office for having given you your letter .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: It 's been a great treat to us to come and see you . And it 's done my heart good to see Lady Little . If you do n't mind my saying so she 's like a spring morning and it makes one glad to be alive just to look at her .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , do n't !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm inclined to feel very kindly to everyone who feels kindly towards her . You must enjoy yourselves in Upper Egypt and when you come back to Cairo you must let us know .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm expecting to learn a good deal from my journey .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You may learn a good deal that will surprise you . You may learn that there are races in the world that seem born to rule and races that seem born to serve ; that democracy is not a panacea for all the ills of mankind , but merely one system of government like another , which has n't had a long enough trial to make it certain whether it is desirable or not ; that freedom generally means the power of the strong to oppress the weak , and that the wise statesman gives men the illusion of it but not the substance — in short , a number of things which must be very disturbing to the equilibrium of a Radical Member of Parliament .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: On the other hand , you 'll see our beautiful Nile and the temples .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: And perhaps they 'll suggest to you that however old the world is it 's ever young , and that when all 's said and done the most permanent on the face of the earth is what seems the most transitory — the ideal .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Fanny , it looks to me as though we 'd bitten off as big a piece of cake as we can chew with any comfort .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , well , we 'll do our best . And though I never could do arithmetic I 've always thought perhaps one might be saved without . Good-bye , Lady Little , and thank you for having us .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Good-bye .

div.stage: There are general farewells and they go to the door . RONNY opens it for them . They go out .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I forgot to tell you , sir , Mrs. Pritchard has just telephoned to ask if she can see you on a matter of business .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a grim smile .Say I 'm very busy to-day , and I regret exceedingly that it will be quite impossible for me to see her .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: With a twinkle in his eye .She said she was coming round at once .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If she 's made up her mind to see me at all costs she might have saved herself the trouble of ringing up to find out if it was convenient .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Your sister is a determined creature , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I know . I have some authority in the affairs of this country , but none over dear Christina . I wonder what she wants .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Let us hope for the best .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 've noticed that whenever anyone wants to see me very urgently it 's never to give me anything . When Christina wants to see me urgently my only safety is in instant flight .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You must be nice to her , Arthur . If you 're not she 'll only take it out of me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's monstrous , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: After all , she kept house for you for ten years . Admirably , mind you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Admirably . She has a genius for order and organisation in the house . Everything went like clockwork . She never wasted a farthing . She saved me hundreds of pounds . She led me a dog 's life . I 've come to the conclusion there 's nothing so detestable as a good housekeeper .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How fortunate you married me , then ! But you can n't expect her to see that point of view . It 's very hard for her to be turned out of this very pleasant billet , and it 's natural that when you wo n't do something she asks you she should put it down to my influence .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It must have been a very difficult position for you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I did all I could to make her like me . I did feel rather like a usurper , you know . I tried to make her see that I did n't at all want to put on airs .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Fortunately she 's taken it very well . I confess I was a little nervous when she told me she meant to stay on in Egypt to be near her son .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It would be a detestable person who did n't like Violet , I think .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Detestable . I should have no hesitation in having him deported .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I think I 'd better be getting back to my work .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh , Ronny , would you like me to come and help you with your packing ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: To RONNY .Are you going somewhere ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'm leaving Cairo .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Did n't you know ? Ronny has just been appointed to Paris .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is he going to leave Egypt for good ?

div.stage: She is taken aback by the news . She clenches her hand on the rail of a chair ; ARTHUR and ANNE notice the little , instinctive motion .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I suppose so .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: But why was it kept from me ? Why have you been making a secret of it ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Darling , no one 's been making a secret of it . I — I thought Anne would have told you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , it does n't matter at all , but Ronny has been in the habit of doing all sorts of things for me . It would have been convenient if I 'd been told that a change was going to be made .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm very sorry . It was only arranged this morning . I received a telegram from the Foreign Office . I thought it would interest Anne , so I sent Ronny along to tell her .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I hate to be treated like a child .

div.stage: There is a moment 's embarrassment .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It was stupid of me . I ought to have come and told you . I was so pleased and excited that I forgot .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't quite know why you should have been so excited .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It will be very nice for me to have Ronny so near . You see , now I 've given up my flat I sha n't come to Egypt very often and I should never have seen Ronny . I can run over to Paris constantly . Besides , it 's a step , is n't it ? And I want to see him an Ambassador before I die .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't see what good it will do him in Paris to speak Arabic like a native .

lg.l: Oh , well , that is the F. O . all over . The best Persian scholar in the
Service has spent the last six years in Washington .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's been a great surprise for me . I expected to remain in Egypt indefinitely .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Recovering herself .I expect you 'll have a very good time in Paris . When do you go ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: There 's a boat the day after to-morrow . Sir Arthur thought I 'd better take that .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Scarcely mistress of herself .As soon as that !Recovering , gaily .We shall miss you dreadfully . I can n't imagine what I shall do without you .To ANNE .You can n't think how useful he 's been to me since I came here .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's very kind of you to say so .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: He 's invaluable at functions and things like that . You see , he knows where everyone should sit at dinner . And at first he used to coach me with details about various people so that I should n't say the wrong thing .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If you had you 'd have said it so charmingly that no one would have resented it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm so afraid that the man who takes Ronny 's place will refuse to write my invitations for me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's not exactly the duty of my secretaries .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , but I do hate doing it myself . And Ronny was able to imitate my handwriting .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm sure he could never write as badly as you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , yes , he could . Could n't you ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I managed to write quite enough like you for people not to notice the difference .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You know , there are thirty-two invitations to do now .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why do n't you send cards ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , I think a letter is so much more polite . Somehow I do n't feel old enough to ask people to dine with me in the third person .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'll come and do them the moment Sir Arthur can let me go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 'd better do them before Violet goes out .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: That 'll be very soon . The Khedive 's mother has asked me to go and see her at half-past three . I 'll get the list now , shall I ? I do n't think I 'll wait for Christina . If she wants to see you on business I dare say she 'd rather I was n't there .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Very well .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: To RONNY .Will you come here when you 're ready ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Certainly .

div.stage: She goes out .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Have you finished that report yet ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Not quite , sir . It will be ready in ten minutes .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Put it on my desk .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: All right , sir .

div.stage: Exit . ARTHUR and ANNE are left alone . He looks at her reflectively .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Violet is very sensitive to anything that might be considered a slight .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It 's very natural , is n't it ? A high-spirited girl .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: She likes me to tell her my arrangements . It gives her a little feeling of importance to know things before other people .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh , of course . I quite understand . I should do the same in her place .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I ought to have remembered and told her that Ronny was going . She was just a little vexed because she thought I 'd been fixing things up behind her back .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , I know . It would naturally put her out for a moment to learn on a sudden that one of the persons she 'd been thrown in contact with was going away .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a twinkle in his eye .I 'm wondering if I must blame you for the loss of an excellent secretary .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Me ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't know why the F. O . should suddenly have made up their minds that your brother was wanted in Paris . Have you been pulling strings ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Smiling .What a suspicious nature you have !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Anne , own up .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I thought Ronny was getting into a groove here . There did n't seem to be much more for him to do than he has been doing for some time . If you will have the truth , I 've been moving heaven and earth to get him moved .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: How deceitful of you not to have said a word about it !

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I did n't want to make him restless . I knew he 'd be mad to go to Paris . I thought it much better not to say anything till it was settled .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: D'you think he 's mad to go to Paris ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Fencing with him .Any young man would be .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I wonder if he 'd be very much disappointed if I made other arrangements .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: What do you mean , Arthur ? You would n't prevent him from going when I 've done everything in the world to get him away .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Abruptly .Why should you be so anxious for him to go ?

div.stage: She looks at him for an instant in dismay .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Good heavens , do n't speak so sharply to me . I told Violet just now . I wanted him to be more get-at-able . I think he stands a much better chance of being noticed if he 's in a place like Paris .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a smile .Ah , yes , you said you were coming less frequently to Egypt than in the past . It might be worth while to keep Ronny here in order to tempt you back .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Egypt is n't the same to me that it was .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I hope my marriage has made no difference to our friendship , Anne . You know how deeply I value it .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You used to come and see me very often . You knew I was discreet and you used to talk over with me all sorts of matters which occupied you . I was pleased and flattered . Of course I realised that those pleasant conversations of ours must stop when you married . I only came here this winter to collect my goods and chattels .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You make me feel vaguely guilty towards you .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Of course you 're nothing of the sort . But I do n't want Violet to feel that I am making any attempt to — to monopolise you . She 's been charming to me . The more I know her the more delightful I find her .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's very nice of you to say so .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You know I 've always had a great admiration for you . I 'm so glad to see you married to a girl who 's not unworthy of you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I suppose it was a dangerous experiment for a man of my age to marry a girl of nineteen .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I think one can admit that . But you 've always been one of the favourites of the gods . You 've made a wonderful success of it .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It needs on a husband 's part infinite tact , patience , and tolerance .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You have the great advantage that Violet is genuinely in love with you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I suppose only a fatuous ass would confess that a beautiful girl was in love with him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You make her very happy .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: There 's nothing I would n't do to achieve that . I 'm more desperately in love with Violet even than when I first married her .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'm so glad . I want nothing but your happiness .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Here is Christina .

div.stage: The door opens as he says these words and an English BUTLER ushers in MRS. PRITCHARD . She is a tall , spare woman , with hair turning grey , comely , upright in her carriage , with decision of character indicated by every gesture ; but though masterful and firm to attain her ends , she is an honest woman , direct , truthful and not without humour . She is admirably gowned in a manner befitting her station and importance .

sp.speaker: BUTLER
sp.p: Mrs. Pritchard .

div.stage: Exit .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I knew it was you , Christina . I felt a sense of responsibility descend upon the house .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Kissing him .How is Violet ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Lovely .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I was inquiring about her health .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Her health is perfect .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: At her age one 's always well , I suppose .Kissing ANNE .How d'you do ? And how are you , my poor Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You ask me as though I was a doddering old gentleman , crippled with rheumatism . I 'm in the best of health , thank you very much , and very active for my years .CHRISTINA has seen a flower on the table that has fallen from a bowl , and picks it up and puts it back in its place .Why do you do that ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't like untidiness .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do .

div.stage: He takes the flower out again and places it on the table .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I was expecting to find you in your office .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do you think I 'm neglecting my work ? I thought it more becoming to wait for you here .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I wanted to see you on a matter of business .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: So I understood from your message . I feel convinced you 're going to put me in the way of making my fortune .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'll leave you , shall I ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Oh , no , pray do n't . There 's not the least reason why you should n't hear what it 's all about .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 're not going to make my fortune after all . You 're going to ask me to do something .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: What makes you think that ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You want a third person present to be witness to my brutal selfishness when I refuse . I know you , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Smiling .You 're much too sensible to refuse a perfectly reasonable request .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Let us hear it .She sits down on the sofa . The cushions have been disordered by people sitting on them and she shakes them out , and pats them and arranges them in their place .I wish you 'd leave the furniture alone , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I cannot make out what pleasure people take in seeing things out of their proper place .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 're very long in coming to the point .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I hear that the Khedive has quarrelled with his secretary .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 're a marvellous woman , Christina . You get hold of all the harem gossip .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: It 's true , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Yes . But I only heard of it myself just before luncheon . How did it come to your ears ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: That does n't matter , does it ? I have a way of hearing things that may be of interest to me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm very dense , but I do n't see how it can be of any particular interest to you .

lg.l: Dear Arthur . The Khedive has asked you to recommend him an
English secretary .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Has he really ? That 's a change . He 's never had an English secretary before .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Never .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It 's a wonderful opportunity .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If we get the right man he can be of the greatest possible help . If he 's tactful , wise , and courteous , there 's no reason why in time he should n't attain very considerable influence over the Khedive . If we can really get the Khedive to work honestly and sincerely with us , instead of hampering us by all kinds of secret devices , we can do miracles in this country .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: What a splendid chance for the man who gets the job !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I suppose it is . If he has the right qualities he may achieve anything . And after all , it 's a splendid chance to be able to render such great service to our own old country .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Has the Khedive given any particulars about the sort of man he wants ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: He naturally wants a young man and a good sportsman . It 's important that he should be able to speak Arabic . But the qualifications which will satisfy the Khedive are nothing beside those which will satisfy me . The wrong man may cause irreparable damage to British interests .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Have you thought that Henry would be admirably suited ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I can n't say I have , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: He 's young and he 's very good at games . He speaks Arabic .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Quite well , I believe . I think he 's very well suited to the post he has . It would be a pity to disturb him when he 's just got at home with the work .

lg.l: Arthur , you can n't compare a very badly paid job in the Ministry of
Education with a private secretaryship to the Khedive .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The best job for a man is the one he 's most fitted to do .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 've got no fault to find with Henry . He 's a very good worker , he 's honest , industrious , and painstaking .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You do n't praise a pair of boots because you can walk in them without discomfort ; if you can n't you chuck them away .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: What d'you mean by that ?

lg.l: The qualities you mention really do n't deserve any particular reward . If
Henry had n't got them I 'd fire him without a moment 's hesitation .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I have no doubt you 'd welcome the opportunity . It 's the greatest misfortune of Henry 's life that he happens to be your nephew .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: On the other hand , it 's counterbalanced by his extraordinary good luck in being your son .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 've stood in his way on every possible occasion .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Good-humouredly .You know that 's not true , Christina . I 've refused to perpetrate a number of abominable jobs that you 've urged me to . He 's had his chances as everyone else has . You 're an admirable mother . If I 'd listened to you he 'd be Commander-in-Chief and Prime Minister by now .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I 've never asked you to do anything for Henry that was n't perfectly reasonable .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's evident then that we have different views upon what is reasonable .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I appeal to you , Anne : do you see any objection to suggesting Henry to the Khedive as a private secretary ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I knew that 's what she wanted you here for , Anne , to be a witness to my pig-headed obstinacy .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't be absurd , Arthur . I 'm asking Anne for an unprejudiced opinion .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Anne is unlikely to have an opinion of any value on a matter she knows nothing about .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With a chuckle .That is a very plain hint that I can n't do better than hold my tongue . I 'll take it , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: It 's so unreasonable of you , Arthur . You wo n't listen to any argument .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The only one you 've offered yet is : here 's a good job going , Henry 's your nephew , give it him . My dear , do n't you see the Khedive would never accept such a near relation of mine ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't agree with you at all . The fact of his asking you to recommend an English secretary shows that he wants to draw the connection between you and himself closer . After all , you might give the boy a chance .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: This is not an occasion when one can afford to give a chance . It 's hit or miss . If the man I choose is a failure the Khedive will never ask me to do such a thing for him again . I can n't take any risks .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Will you tell me what qualifications Henry lacks to make him suitable for the post ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Certainly . It 's true he speaks Arabic , but he does n't understand the native mind . Grammars can n't teach you that , my dear , only sympathy . He has the mind of an official . I often think that you must have swallowed a ramrod in early life and poor Henry was born with a foot-rule in his inside .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I am not amused , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I have no doubt in course of time he 'll become a very competent official , but he 'll never be anything else . He lacks imagination , and that is just as necessary to a statesman as to a novelist . Finally he has no charm .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: How can you judge ? You 're his uncle . You might just as well say I have no charm .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You have n't . You 're an admirable woman , with all the substantial virtues which make you an ornament to your sex , but you have no charm .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: With a grim smile .I should be a fool if I expected you to pay me compliments , should n't I ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You would at all events be a woman who is unable to learn by experience .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Besides , I do n't agree with you . I think Henry has charm .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why do we all call him Henry ? Why does Henry suit him so admirably ? If he had charm we would naturally call him Harry .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Really , Arthur , it amazes me that a man in your position can be influenced by such absurd trifles . It 's so unfair , when a boy has a dozen solid real virtues that you should refuse to recommend him for a job because he has n't got in your opinion a frivolous , unsubstantial advantage like charm .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Unsubstantial it may be , but frivolous it certainly is n't . Believe me , charm is the most valuable asset that any man can have . D'you think it sounds immoral to say it compensates for the lack of brains and virtue ? Alas ! it happens to be true . Brains may bring you to power , but charm enables you to keep it . Without charm you will never lead men .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: And do you imagine you 're likely to find a young Englishman who 's a sportsman and an Arabic scholar , who has tact , imagination , sympathy , wisdom , courtesy and charm ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: If you do , Arthur , I 'm afraid he wo n't remain here very long , because I warn you , I shall insist on marrying him .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's not so formidable as it sounds . I 'm going to suggest Ronny .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Astounded .Ronald Parry ! That 's the very last person I should have thought you 'd be inclined to suggest .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Sharply .Why ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With dismay .You do n't really mean that , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: To ANNE .Did n't you know ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: It 's the last thing that would ever have entered my head .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I thought you 'd made all arrangements for sending him away .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I made no arrangements at all . I received a telegram from the F. O . saying that he 'd been appointed to Paris .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: After a very short pause .Do n't you think you 'd better leave it at that ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No , I do n't . I 'm going to wire to London explaining the circumstances and suggesting that I think him very suitable for the post that 's just offered itself .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Trying to take it lightly .I feel rather aggrieved , after all the efforts I 've made to get him appointed to Paris .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Oh , he owes that to you , does he ? You thought it would be better for him to leave here ?

lg.l: I do n't quite understand what you 're driving at ,
Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Taking him up defiantly .I cannot imagine anyone more unsuitable than Ronald Parry .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That is for me to judge , is n't it ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Perhaps the Foreign Office will say they see no reason to change their mind .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't think so .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Have you told Ronny ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No , I thought it unnecessary till I 'd found out whether the Khedive would be willing to take him .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I 'm amazed , Arthur . When Henry told me Ronald Parry was going I could n't help thinking it was very desirable .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why ?

div.stage: She looks at him , about to speak , then hesitates . She does not dare , and resolves to be silent . ANNE comes to the rescue .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Christina knows that I shall be very little in Egypt in future and how fond Ronny and I are of one another . We naturally want to be as near each other as we can .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: With a chuckle .It really amuses me that you should refuse to give a good job to Henry because you 've made up your mind to give it to Ronald Parry .

div.stage: ARTHUR walks up to her deliberately and faces her .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If you 've got anything to say against him say it .

div.stage: They stare at one another for a moment in silence .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: If you have nothing against him there 's no reason why I should .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I see . I have a good deal to do this afternoon . If you have nothing more to say to me I 'd like to get back to my work .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Very well , I 'll go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You wo n't stop and see Violet ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't think so , thank you .

div.stage: She goes out . He opens the door for her .

lg.l: Why did n't you tell me just now that you 'd decided to keep Ronny in
Cairo ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I thought it was unnecessary till everything was settled . I daresay you 'll be good enough to hold your tongue about it .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Have you definitely made up your mind ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Definitely .

div.stage: They look at one another steadily .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I think I 'll go up to my room . I keep to my old habit of a siesta after luncheon .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I wish I could get Violet to take it .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: She 's so young , she does n't feel the need of it yet .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Yes , she 's so young .

div.stage: ANNE goes out . For a moment ARTHUR gives way to discouragement . He feels old and tired . But he hears a footstep and pulls himself together . He is his usual self , gay , gallant and humorous , when VIOLET enters the room .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I saw Christina drive away . What did she want ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The earth .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I hope you gave it her .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No , I 'm trying to get the moon for you just now , darling , and I thought if I gave her the earth it really would upset the universe a little too much .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I thought I 'd better do these invitations before I dressed .

lg.l: You 're not going to put on a different frock to go and have tea with the
Khedive 's mother ? You look charming in that .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I think it 's a little too young . It was all right for the morning .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Of course you are older this afternoon , that 's quite true .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Can you spare Ronny just now ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: After an instant 's pause .Yes , I 'll send him to you at once .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: As he is going .I shall be back in time to give you your tea .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That will be very nice . Good-bye till then .

div.stage: He goes out . She is meditative . She gives a slight start as RONNY comes in .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I hope I have n't torn you away from anything very important .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I was only typing a very dull report . I 'd just finished it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You must n't ever bother about me if it 's not convenient , you know .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I sha n't have much chance , shall I ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No .... Look , here 's the list .

div.stage: She hands him a sheet of paper on which names are scribbled , and he reads it .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It looks rather a stodgy party , does n't it ? I see you 've crossed my name out .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's not much good asking you when you wo n't be here . Whom d'you advise me to ask in your place ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I do n't know . I hate the idea of anyone being asked in my place . Shall I start on them at once ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If you do n't mind . I have to go out , you know .

div.stage: He sits down at a writing table .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'll start on those I dislike least .

lg.l: Do n't you remember when Arthur said I must ask the
Von Scheidleins how we hated to write them a civil letter ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Writing .Dear Lady Sinclair .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , she asked me to call her Evelyn .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Hang ! I 'll have to start again .

lg.l: It always make me so uncomfortable to address fat old ladies by their
Christian names .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'll end up “ yours affectionately , ” shall I ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I suppose you 're awfully excited at the thought of going ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's a step for you , is n't it ? I ... I ought to congratulate you .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You do n't think I want to go , do you ? I hate it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 've been very happy here .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You knew you could n't stay here for the rest of your life .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Why not ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: With an effort at self-control .Who is the next person on the list ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Looking at it .Will you miss me at all ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I suppose I shall at first .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: That 's not a very kind thing to say .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is n't it ? I do n't mean to be unkind , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , I 'm so miserable !

div.stage: She gives a little cry and looks at him . She presses her hands to her heart .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Let us go on with the letters .

div.stage: Silently he writes . She does not watch him , but looks hopelessly into space . She is unable to restrain a sob .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You 're crying .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , I 'm not . I 'm not . I swear I 'm not .He gets up and goes over to her . He looks into her eyes .It came so suddenly . I never dreamt you 'd be going away .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , Violet !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do n't call me that . Please do n't .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Did you know that I loved you ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How should I know ? Oh , I 'm so unhappy . What have I done to deserve it ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I could n't help loving you . It can n't matter if I tell you now . It 's the end of everything . I do n't want to go without your knowing . I love you . I love you . I love you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , Ronny !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's been so wonderful , all these months . I 've never known anyone to come up to you . Everything you said pleased me . I loved the way you walk , and your laugh , and the sound of your voice .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , do n't !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I was content just to see you and to talk with you and to know you were here , near me . You 've made me extraordinarily happy .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Have I ? Oh , I 'm so glad .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I could n't help myself . I tried not to think of you . You 're not angry with me ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I can n't be . Oh , Ronny , I 've had such a rotten time . It came upon me unawares , I did n't know what was happening . I thought I only liked you .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , my dearest ! Is it possible ...?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And when it struck me — oh , I was so frightened . I thought it must be written on my face and everyone must see . I knew it was wrong . I knew I must n't . I could n't help myself .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , say it , Violet . I want to hear you say it : “ I love you . ”

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I love you .He kneels down before her and covers her hands with kisses .Oh , do n't , do n't !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: My dearest . My very dearest .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What have I done ? I made up my mind that no one should ever know . I thought then it would n't matter . It need n't prevent me from doing my duty to Arthur . It did n't interfere with my affection for him . I did n't see how it could hurt anyone if I kept my love for you locked up in my heart , tightly , and it made me so happy . I rejoiced in it .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I never knew . I used to weigh every word you said to me . You never gave me a sign .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I did n't know it was possible to love anybody as I love you , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: My precious !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , do n't say things like that to me . It breaks my heart . I would n't ever have told you only I was upset by your going . If they 'd only given me time to get used to the thought I would n't ... I would n't make such a fool of myself .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You can n't grudge me that little bit of comfort .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: But it all came so suddenly , the announcement that you were going and your going . I felt I could n't bear it . Why did n't they give me time ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Do n't cry , my dearest , it tortures me .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: This is the last time we shall be alone , Ronny . I could n't let you go without ... oh , my God , I can n't bear it .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: We might have been so happy together , Violet . Why did n't we meet sooner ? I feel we 're made for one another .

lg.l: Oh , do n't talk of that . D'you suppose I have n't said to myself : “ Oh , if
I 'd only met him first ” ? Oh , Ronny , Ronny , Ronny !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I never dared to think that you loved me . It 's maddening that I must go . It 's horrible to think of leaving you now .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , it 's better . We could n't have gone on like that . I 'm glad you 're going . It breaks my heart .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , Violet , why did n't you wait for me ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I made a mistake . I must pay for it . Arthur 's so good and kind . He loves me with all his heart . Oh , what a fool I was ! I did n't know what love was . I feel that my life is finished , and I 'm so young , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You know I 'd do anything in the world for you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: My dear one .They stand , face to face , looking at one another wistfully and sadly .It 's no good , Ronny , we 're both making ourselves utterly miserable . Say good-bye to me and let us part .He draws her towards him .No , do n't kiss me . I do n't want you to kiss me .He takes her in his arms and kisses her passionately .Oh , Ronny , I do love you so .At last she tears herself away from him . She sinks into a chair . He makes a movement towards her .No , do n't come near me now . I 'm so tired .

div.stage: He looks at her for a moment , then he goes back to the table and sits down to write the letters . Their eyes meet slowly .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's good-bye , then ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's good-bye .She presses her hands to her heart as though the aching were unendurable . He buries his head in his hands .END OF THE FIRST ACT

div.head: ACT II

stage.stage: The scene is the garden of the Consular Agent 's residence . It is an Eastern garden with palm-trees , magnolias , and flowering bushes of azaleas . On one side is an old Arabic well-head decorated with verses from the Koran ; a yellow rambler grows over the ironwork above . Rose-trees are in full bloom . On the other side are basket chairs and a table . At the bottom of the garden runs the Nile and on the farther bank are lines of palm-trees and the Eastern sky . It is towards evening and during the act the sun gradually sets .

The table is set out with tea-things . ANNE is seated reading a book . The gardener in his blue gaberdine , with brown legs and the little round cap of the Egyptian workman , is watering the flowers . CHRISTINA comes in .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Looking up , with a smile .Ah , Christina !

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I was told I should find you here . I came to see Violet , but I hear she has n't come back yet .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: She was going to see the Khedive 's mother .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I think I 'll wait for her .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Would you like tea ? I was waiting till Violet came in . I expect she 's been made to eat all sorts of sweet things and she 'll want a cup of tea to take the taste out of her mouth .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: No , do n't have it brought for me .... I can never quite get over being treated as a guest in the house I was mistress of for so many years .To the Gardener .ImshiGet out

sp.speaker: GARDENER
sp.p: Detak sa ‘ idehMay thy night be happy

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Your knowledge of Arabic is rather sketchy , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I never see why I should trouble myself with strange languages . If foreigners want to talk to me they can talk to me in English .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: But surely when we 're out of our own country we 're foreigners .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Nonsense , Anne , we 're English . I wonder Arthur allows Violet to learn Arabic . I can n't help thinking it 'll make a bad impression on the natives . I managed this house on fifty words of Arabic .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Smiling .I 'm convinced that on a hundred you 'd be prepared to manage the country .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't think you can deny that I did my work here competently .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You 're a wonderful housekeeper .

lg.l: I have common sense and a talent for organisation .
It breaks my heart to see the way certain things are done here now .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You must remember Violet is very young .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Much too young to be a suitable wife for Arthur .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: He seems to be very well satisfied , and after all he is the person most concerned .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I know . His infatuation is — blind , do n't you think ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Coolly .I think it 's very delightful to see two people so much in love with one another .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: D'you know that I used to be fearfully jealous of you , Anne ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Amused .I know that you thoroughly disliked me , Christina . You did n't trouble to hide it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I was always afraid that Arthur would marry you . I did n't want to be turned out of this house . I suppose you think that 's horrid of me .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: No , I think it 's very natural .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I did n't see why Arthur should marry . I gave him all the comforts of home life . And I thought it would interfere with his work . Of course I knew that he liked you . I suffered agonies when he used to go and dine with you quietly .With a sniff .He said it rested him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Perhaps it did . Did you grudge him that ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I knew you were desperately in love with him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Need you throw that in my face now ? Really , I have n't deserved it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: My dear , I wish he had married you . It never struck me he 'd marry a girl twenty years younger than himself .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: He never looked upon me as anything but a friend . I do n't suppose it occurred to him for an instant that my feeling might possibly be different .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: It was stupid of me . I ought to have given him a hint .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With a smile .You took care not to do that , Christina . Perhaps you knew that was all it wanted .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Reflectively .I do n't think he 's treated you very well .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Nonsense . A man is n't obliged to marry a woman just because she 's in love with him . I do n't see why loving should give one a claim on the person one loves .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You would have made him a splendid wife .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: So will Violet , my dear . Most men have the wives they deserve .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I marvel at your kindness to her . You 're so tolerant and sympathetic , one would never imagine she 's robbed you of what you wanted most in the world .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I should n't respect myself very much if I bore her the shadow of a grudge . I 'm so glad that she 's sweet and charming and ingenuous ; it makes it very easy to be fond of her .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I know . I wanted to dislike her . But I can n't really . There is something about her which disarms one .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Is n't it lucky ? It 's a difficult position . That irresistible charm of hers will make everything possible . After all , you and I can agree in that we both want Arthur to be happy .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I wonder if there 's much chance of that .

div.stage: ANNE looks at her for a moment inquiringly , and CHRISTINA coolly returns the stare .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why did you come here this afternoon , Christina ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: With a faint smile .Why did you take so much trouble to get your brother moved to Paris ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Good heavens , I told you this morning .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: D'you think we need make pretences with one another ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I do n't think I quite understand .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't you ? You wanted Ronny to leave Egypt because you know he 's in love with Violet .

div.stage: For a moment ANNE is a little taken aback , but she quickly recovers herself .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: He 's very susceptible . He 's always falling in and out of love . I had noticed that he was attracted , and I confess I thought it better to put him out of harm 's way .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: How cunning you are , Anne ! You wo n't admit anything till you 're quite certain the person you 're talking to knows it . You know as well as I do that Violet is just as much in love with him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Much disturbed .Christina , what are you going to do ? How could I help knowing ? You 've only got to see the way they look at one another . They 're sick with love .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: What did Arthur expect ? I 've never seen a couple more admirably suited to one another .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I thought no one knew but me till this morning , when you were talking to Arthur . Then I thought you must know too . My heart was in my mouth , I was afraid you were going to tell him . But you did n't , and I thought I 'd been mistaken .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You did n't give me credit for very nice feeling , Anne . Because I did n't act like a perfect beast you thought I must be a perfect fool .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I know how devoted you are to your son . I did n't believe you 'd stick at anything when his interests were at stake . I 'm sorry , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Pray do n't apologise . I did n't know it myself . It was on the tip of my tongue to tell Arthur , but I simply could n't . I could n't do anything so shabby .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Oh , Christina , we must n't ever let him know , we can n't make him so miserable . It would break his heart .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Well , what is to be done ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Heaven knows . I 've been racking my brains . I can think of nothing . I 'd arranged everything so beautifully . And now I 'm helpless . I thought even of going to Ronny and asking him to refuse any job that will keep him here . But Arthur looks upon it as so important . He 'll insist on Ronny 's accepting unless his reasons for going are — what 's the word I want ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Irrefutable . It seems very hard that my boy should be done out of such a splendid chance by Ronny . Except for your brother I 'm sure Arthur would give it to Henry .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Diplomatically .I know he has the highest opinion of Henry 's abilities .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You can n't expect me to sit still and let things go on .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Arthur is perfectly unconscious . He thinks Violet is as much in love with him as he is with her . You could n't be so cruel as to hint anything to him .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: How you adore him , Anne ! You may set your mind at rest . I 'm not going to say a word to Arthur . I 'm going to speak to Violet .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Frightened .What are you going to say ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I 'm going to ask her to do all she can to persuade Arthur to give Henry the job . And then Ronny can go to Paris .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You 're not going to tell her you know ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Deliberately .If it 's necessary she must make Ronny refuse the appointment . He must invent some excuse that Arthur will accept .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: But it 's blackmail .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't care what it is .

div.stage: VIOLET comes in . She wears an afternoon gown , picturesque and simple , yet elegant enough for the visit she has been paying . She has a large hat , which she presently removes .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Here is Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , you poor people , have n't you had any tea ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I thought we 'd wait till you came back . It 'll come at once now .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How are you , Christina ? How is Henry ?They kiss one another .I 've not seen him for days .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: He 's coming to fetch me presently .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I shall tell him he neglects me . He 's the only one of my in-laws I 'm not a little afraid of .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: He 's a good boy .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: He has a good mother . I thought it would be such fun having a nephew several years older than myself , but he wo n't treat me as an aunt . He will call me Violet . I tell him he ought to be more respectful .

div.stage: Meanwhile SERVANTS have brought the tea .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: What have you been doing this afternoon ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , I went to see the Khedive 's mother . She made me eat seventeen different things and I feel exactly like a boa-constrictor .Looking at the cakes and scones .I 'm afraid there 's not a very nice tea .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: So I notice .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: With a smile .I suppose I could n't persuade you to pour it out .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Gratified .Certainly , if you wish it .

div.stage: She sits down in front of the teapot and pours out cups of tea . ARTHUR comes in .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Hulloa , Christina , are you pouring out the tea ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Violet asked me to .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If only I were n't here it would be quite like old times .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I understand you want to see me , Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , I hope you have n't come out here on purpose . I sent the message that I wished to have a word with you when convenient , but I did n't want to hurry you . I was quite prepared to go to you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That sounds very formidable . I had a few minutes to spare while some letters were being prepared for me to sign . But in any case I 'm always at your service .

lg.l: The Khedive 's mother has asked me to talk to you about a man called
Abdul Said .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: She thought if I put the circumstances before you ....

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Interrupting .What has he got to do with her ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: He 's been employed for years on an estate of hers up the Nile . His mother was one of her maids . It appears she gave her a dowry when she married .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Smiling .I see . I gathered that Abdul Said had powerful influence somewhere or other .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Who is this man , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: He 's been sentenced to death for murder . It was a perfectly clear case , but there was a lot of perjury and we had some difficulty in getting a conviction . What has the Princess asked you to do ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: She explained the whole thing to me , and then she asked if I would n't intercede with you . I promised to do everything I could .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You should n't have done that . The old lady knows quite well an affair of this sort is no business of yours . I wish you 'd told her so .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur , what could I do ? His wife was there , and his mother . If you 'd seen them .... I could n't bear to look at their misery and do nothing . I said I was sure that when you knew all the facts you 'd reprieve the man .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's not in my power to do anything of the sort . The prerogative of mercy is with the Khedive .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I know , but if you advise him to exercise it he will . He 's only too anxious to , but he wo n't move without your advice .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's monstrous of the Princess to try and make use of you in this way . She prepared a complete trap for you .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: What did the man do exactly ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's rather a peculiar case . Abdul Said had a difference of opinion with an Armenian merchant and shortly after his only son fell ill and died . He took it into his head that the Armenian had cast the evil eye on him , and he took his gun , waited for his opportunity , and shot the Armenian dead . The man is n't a criminal in the ordinary sense of the word , but we can n't afford to make exceptions . If we did there 'd be a crop of murders with the same excuse . I looked into the case this morning and I see no reason to advise the Khedive to interfere with the course of justice .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: This morning ? When you came in to luncheon full of spirits , laughing and chaffing , had you just sent a man to his death ? How horribly callous !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm sorry you should think that . I give every matter my closest attention , and when I 've settled it to the best of my ability I put it out of my mind . I think it would be just as unwise to let it affect me as for a doctor to let himself be affected by his patients ’ sufferings .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It seems to me horrible to slaughter that wretched man because he 's ignorant and simple-minded . Do n't you see that for yourself ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm not here to interpret the law according to my feelings but according to its own spirit .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's easy to talk like that when you have n't got any feeling one way or the other . Do n't you realise the misery of that man condemned to die for what he honestly thought was a mere act of justice ? I wish you 'd seen the agony of those poor women . And now they 're more or less happy because I promised to help them . The Princess told them I had influence with you . If she only knew !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You should never have been put in such a position . It was grossly unfair . I 'll take care that nothing of the sort occurs again .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you mean to say you 'll do nothing ? Wo n't you even go into the matter again — with a little sympathy ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I can n't !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's the first thing I 've ever asked you , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I know . I 'm only sorry that I must refuse you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: This is the first sentence of death in Egypt since our marriage . Do n't you know what it would mean to me to think I 'd saved a man 's life ? The Khedive is waiting to sign the reprieve . It only requires a word from you . Wo n't you say it ? I feel that the gratitude of these poor women may be like a blessing on us .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , I think my duty is very clear . I must do it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's clear because all that grief means nothing to you . What do you care if a man is hanged whom you 've never even seen ? I wonder if you 'd find it so easy to do your duty in a matter that affected you . If it meant misery or happiness to you . It 's easy to do one 's duty when one does n't care .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 're quite right . That is the test : if one can do one 's duty when it means the loss of all one holds dear and valuable in the world .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I hope you 'll never be put to it .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a chuckle .My dear , you say that as though you hoped precisely the contrary .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Must I write to the Princess and say I was entirely mistaken , and I have no more influence over you than a tripper at Shepheard 's Hotel ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'd sooner you did n't write to her at all . I will have a message conveyed which you may be sure will save you from any humiliation .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Icily .I 'm afraid you have a lot of business ; you must n't let me keep you .

div.stage: He looks at her reflectively for a moment and then goes out . There is an awkward silence .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Those good people we had to luncheon to-day would be amused to see what the power amounts to that they congratulated me on .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: There 's very little that Arthur would refuse you . He 'd do practically anything in the world to please you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 'll be a long time before I ask him to do anything else .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't say that , Violet . Because I came here to-day on purpose to ask you to use your influence with him .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You see how much I have .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: That was a matter of principle . Men are always funny about principles . You can never get them to understand that circumstances alter cases .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur looks upon me as a child . After all , it 's not my fault that I 'm twenty years younger than he is .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I want your help so badly , Violet . And you know , the fact that Arthur has just refused to do something for you is just the reason that will make him anxious to do anything you ask now .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't want to expose myself to the humiliation of another refusal .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: It 's so important to me . It may mean all the difference to Henry 's future .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: With a change of manner , charmingly .Oh ! I 'd love to do anything I could for Henry .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: The Khedive has asked Arthur for an English secretary . It seems to me that Henry has every possible qualification , but you know what Arthur is ; he 's terrified of the least suspicion of favouring his friends and relations .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: My dear Christina , what can I do ? Arthur would merely tell me to mind my own business .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: He wants to give the post to Ronald Parry ....

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Quickly .Ronny ? But Ronny 's going to Paris . It 's all arranged .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: It was . But Arthur thinks it essential that he should stay in Egypt .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Did you know this , Anne ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Not till just now .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Does Ronny know ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I do n't think so .

div.stage: VIOLET is aghast . She does all she can to hide her agitation . The two women watch her , CHRISTINA with cold curiosity , ANNE with embarrassment .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm ... I 'm awfully surprised . It 's only an hour or two ago that Ronny and I bade one another a pathetic farewell .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
