sp.p: Really ? But there was never any talk of his going till the day after to-morrow . You were in a great hurry with your leave-takings .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I thought he 'd be busy packing and that I might n't have another chance .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 've been so intimate , I 'm sure he would have been able to snatch a moment to say good-bye to you and Arthur before his train started .

div.stage: VIOLET does not quite know what this speech means . She gives CHRISTINA a look . ANNE comes to the rescue quickly .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Ronny has been acting as Violet 's secretary to a certain extent . I expect they had all sorts of little secrets together that they wanted to discuss in private .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Of course . That 's very natural .With great friendliness .If I thought I were robbing you of anyone who was indispensable to you I would n't ask you to put in a good word for Henry . But , of course , if Ronald became the Khedive 's secretary he could n't exactly continue to write letters and pay bills for you , could he ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm rather taken aback . I 'd got it fixed in my head that Ronny was going .

lg.l: I can promise you that in helping Henry you 're not doing any harm to
Ronald . Anne is very anxious that he should leave Egypt . Is n't that so ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: In a way . Henry is proposing to spend the rest of his official life in Egypt . An appointment like this is naturally more important to him than it would be to Ronny , who is by way of being a bird of passage .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Exactly . Ronny has had his experience here . If he stayed longer it would only be waste of time . Anne naturally wants to have him near her . I daresay she 's a little afraid of his getting into mischief here .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I do n't know about that , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: My dear , you know how susceptible he is . There 's always the possibility that he 'll fall in love with someone who is n't very desirable .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 've got an awful headache .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Why do n't you take a little aspirin ? I 'm quite sure that if you set your mind to it you can persuade Arthur to give the job to Henry . And that would settle everything .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And if I can n't persuade him ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Then you must put it to Ronny .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You see , if he refused the appointment and left Egypt , then I 'm convinced Arthur would accept Henry .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Why should I put it to Ronny ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Pleasantly .You 've been so very friendly , have n't you ? If you suggested to him that ... he 's standing in Henry 's way ....

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I should have thought it was for Anne to do that .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: How simple-minded you are ! A man will often do for a pretty woman what he wo n't do for his sister .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You want me to make him go ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't you think yourself that would be the very best thing ... for all parties ?

div.stage: VIOLET and CHRISTINA look steadily at one another . VIOLET sinks her eyes . She knows that CHRISTINA is aware of her love . She is terrified . RONALD comes in . He is in the highest spirits .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 've been sent to have a cup of tea . Sir Arthur is coming along in a minute . I 've got some news . I 'm staying in Egypt . Is n't it splendid ?

div.stage: VIOLET gives a little gasp .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is it settled then ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Did you know ? I thought it would be a surprise .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No . I 've just heard .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Is n't it magnificent ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 're very changeable . It 's only a few months ago that you were constantly telling Henry you 'd had enough of the country .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Never . I love it . I should like to stay here all my life .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Fancy that !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Addressing himself to VIOLET .It would be madness to leave a place where you 're so happy , would n't it ? I feel so intensely alive here . It 's a wonderful country . One lives every minute of the day .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 're so enthusiastic . One would almost think you 'd fallen in love .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Ronny is naturally enthusiastic .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: To CHRISTINA .And why should n't I have fallen in love ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Wo n't you tell us who with ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: With a chuckle .I was only joking . Is n't it enough to have a splendid job in a country where there 's so much hope ? Sir Arthur has given me a marvellous opportunity . It 'll be my fault if I do n't make the most of it .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Dryly .Shall I give you a cup of tea ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Chaffing her .D'you think I want calming down ? I feel like a prisoner who was going to be hanged and has just had a free pardon . I do n't want to be calmed down . I want to revel in my freedom .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: All that means , I take it , that you do n't want tea .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's no good trying to snub me . I 'm unsnubable to-day . You have n't congratulated me , Anne .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: My dear , you 've been talking nineteen to the dozen . I 've not had the chance to get a word in edgeways .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: To VIOLET .Will you put my name back on your list for that dinner ? It would have broken my heart to miss it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Your official position rather alters things , does n't it ? I would never dare to ask you now just to make an even number .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , well , I 'm sending out the invitations . I shall write a formal letter to myself , explaining the circumstances , and I daresay I shall see my way to accept .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Dear Ronald , you might be eighteen .

div.stage: ARTHUR comes in with HENRY PRITCHARD . This is CHRISTINA 'S son , a pleasant , clean young man , but in no way remarkable .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Henry tells me he 's come to fetch you away , Christina .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: So you lose not a moment in bringing him here .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Really , Christina , you do me an injustice . I can n't bear to think you should be parted from your precious boy an instant longer than necessary .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Shaking hands with VIOLET .How is my stately aunt ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Merry and bright , thank you .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: You know I 'm having a birthday soon , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What of it ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I 've always been given to understand that aunts give their nephews ten shillings on their birthday .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do they ? I am glad . I 'd love to press ten shillings into your willing hand .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Halloa , Ronny . Lucky devil . I congratulate you .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: That 's awfully good of you , old man .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: On what ? Christina !

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I told Henry . I did n't think it would matter , I thought it better that he should know .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I say , Uncle Arthur , I 'm afraid mother has been giving you a rotten time . It 's not my fault , you know .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: What is n't ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Well , when mother told me at luncheon that the Khedive had applied for an English secretary , I saw by the beady look in her eye that if I did n't get the job she was going to make things unpleasant for somebody .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Really , Henry , I do n't know what you mean .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Well , mother , you 're an old dear ....

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Not so old either .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Certainly not , Henry . Let us have none of your nonsense .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: But you know perfectly well that you 'd cheerfully bring the British Empire tumbling about our ears if you could get me a good fat billet by doing so .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Out of the mouths of babes and sucklings ....

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 've got no right to say that , Henry . I 've never asked anything for you that it was n't practically your right to have .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Well , mother , between you and me I do n't mind telling you that Ronny is much more suited to this particular job than I am . Only a perfect fool would have hesitated , and for the honour of the family we can n't suspect Uncle Arthur of being that .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You see what comes of bringing up a boy properly , Christina ; you 've made him a decent fellow in spite of yourself .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: You 're a tiresome creature , Henry , but I 'm attached to you . You may kiss me .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Come along , Mother . I 'm not going to kiss you in public .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Getting up .Well , good-bye , Violet . Do n't forget our little conversation , will you ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Good-bye . Good-bye , Henry .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: To ANNE .Why do n't you come for a little drive with us ? It 's such a beautiful evening .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Will you take me ? I think I 'd like it . It wo n't take me a minute to put on my hat .

div.stage: She gets up . They start to walk towards the house .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Putting up her cheek .Good-bye , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , I 'll just come along and put you in your carriage . You sha n't say that I do n't treat you with the ceremony due to your importance .

div.stage: They saunter off . VIOLET and RONNY are left alone .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're coming back , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , yes , in a minute .Exit .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Under his breath .Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Be quiet .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Is n't it ripping ? I could hardly prevent myself from letting them see how much I loved you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You did n't . Christina suspected before and now you 've told her in plain words .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Gaily .That 's only your fancy . You think because it 's plain to you it must be plain to anybody else .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 've never before had anything to hide . D'you think I like it ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: And even if she does know , what does it matter ? It does her no harm .... And how could anyone help loving you ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Quickly .Take care what you say .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: No one can hear . To look at us anyone would think we were discussing the political situation .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're cunning , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I love you . I love you . I love you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: For God 's sake do n't keep on saying it . I 'm so ashamed .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Astonished .What about ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Just now , this afternoon , I would never have said what I did only I thought you were going . I was n't myself then , Ronny . I ought never to have ....

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Thank God you did . You can n't grudge me the happiness you gave me . You can n't take it away from me now . I know you love me . I hold the sun and the moon in my hands and all the stars of heaven .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Desperately .What are we going to do ? Oh , it 's not fair to me .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It 's done now . You can n't unsay it . Each time I look at you I shall remember . I 've held you in my arms and kissed your lips . You can never take that away from me . And I need n't go . I shall see you constantly . Oh , I 'm so happy .

div.stage: She walks up and down for a moment , trying to control herself , then she makes up her mind : she stops and faces him .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I want you to go , Ronny . I want you to make some excuse and refuse the appointment here .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: No , I can n't leave you now .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I beseech you to go .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Do you want me to ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Yes .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Give me your hand , then .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Give me your hand .She gives it him and he holds it .Say you love me , Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: How cold your hand is !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Let me go .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: D'you really want me to go ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You know I do n't . I adore you . It 'll kill me if you go .He bends down and passionately kisses her hand .Ronny , Ronny , do n't ! What are you doing ?She tears her hand away . She is trembling with emotion . He is white and cold with passion . They sit opposite one another for a while in silence .What a punishment ! When you told me this afternoon that you loved me I thought I 'd never been happy in my life before , and though it tore my heart to think that you must go I felt — oh , I do n't know — as though my joy was so overwhelming , there was no room in my heart for anything else . And now I 'm wretched , wretched .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: But why ? Darling ! My darling , we were going to be parted , and now we 're going to be together . Can anything matter beside that ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's all so hopeless .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It need n't be .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How can it be anything else ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I do n't love you for a day or a week , Violet ; I love you for always .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Whatever happens , I 'm going to try to do my duty to Arthur .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'm not seeking to prevent you . What am I asking for ? I only want to see you . I want to know that I 'm close to you . I want to touch your hand . I want to think of you . What harm can that do you ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If I were my own mistress I could laugh and let you do as you choose . But I 'm not . I 'm bound to you hand and foot . It 's torture to me . And the worst of it is I love my bonds . I can n't wish to be without them . I 'm at your mercy , Ronny . I love you .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , but that 's enough for me . I swear to you I do n't want you to do anything that you 'll ever regret .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If it could only be taken out of our hands . If something would only happen .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: What can happen ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Perhaps the Khedive will change his mind . Perhaps the Foreign Office will say you must go to Paris .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Would you be pleased ? Violet , I want so little from you . How can it hurt you to give me that ? Let us give ourselves a chance to be happy .

lg.l: We shall never be happy . Never . The only thing we can do is to part , and
I can n't let you go . I can n't . I can n't . It 's asking too much of me .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I love you with all my heart and soul . I did n't know it was possible to love anyone as I love you .

div.stage: ARTHUR is heard gaily whistling to himself .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: There 's Arthur !

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Quickly .Shall I go ?

lg.l: Yes . No . Have we got to hide ourselves ? Has it come to that already ? Oh ,
I hate myself .

div.stage: ARTHUR comes in .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Brightly .You 're very gay this afternoon , Arthur . One does n't often hear you whistle .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: D'you think it 's unbecoming to my years or to my dignity ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Shall I give you a cup of tea ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: To tell you the honest truth that is what I came here for .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And I was flattering myself it was for the pleasure of my company .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Ronny , will you find out if it would be convenient for the Khedive to see me at eleven o'clock tohYpppHeNmorrow ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Very good , sir .

div.stage: He goes out .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What have you to see the Khedive about — if it is n't a secret ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Not at all . I 'm merely going to place before him Ronny 's name .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Then the matter 's not definitely settled yet ?

lg.l: Not formally . I 've not had the reply yet to my telegram to the Foreign
Office , and I 've not had the Khedive 's acceptance of my suggestion .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: But supposing the Foreign Office say they think he 'd better go to Paris after all ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I think it 's most unlikely . They know by now that the man on the spot is the best judge of the circumstances , and I 've accustomed them to giving me a free hand .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And you think the Khedive will raise no objection ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: He knows Ronny a little and likes him . I think he 'll be delighted with my choice .

div.stage: There is a pause . ARTHUR drinks his tea . There is no sign that he is conscious of VIOLET 'S agitation . She is tortured by indecision .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur , I 'm sorry if I was cross just now about Abdul Said . It was stupid of me to interfere with something that was n't my business .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , my dear , do n't say that . I 'm sorry I could n't do what you wanted .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I made myself needlessly disagreeable . Will you forgive me ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Darling , do n't reproach yourself . That 's more than I can bear . There 's nothing to forgive .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I owe so much to you . I hate to think that I was horrid .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You do n't owe anything to me at all . And you 're incapable of being horrid .

div.stage: He seizes her hands and is about to kiss them , when she draws them abruptly away .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , do n't kiss my hands .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why not ?

div.stage: He is surprised . For an instant she is taken aback . He looks at her hands and she withdraws them as though he could see on them the kisses which RONNY , a few minutes before , had pressed on them .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: With the faintest laugh of embarrassment .If you want to kiss me I prefer you to kiss my cheeks .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That is evidently what they 're made for .

div.stage: He does not attempt to kiss them . She gives him a quick glance and looks away .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur , I 'm afraid Christina will be awfully disappointed at Henry 's not getting that job .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Let us hope she will bear her disappointment with as much fortitude as I do .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't think she 's entirely given up hope that you will change your mind .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a chuckle .I 'm sure of that . I do n't expect to have much peace till the matter is officially settled . That is why I mean to settle it quickly .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What is your objection to Henry ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: None . He 's not such a good man as Ronald Parry , that 's all .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: The last time there was a good job going Henry just missed getting it .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Henry is one of those men who would do very well for a job if there were n't always somebody just a little bit better applying at the same time .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Christina thinks you 're so anxious not to favour him because he 's your nephew that you are positively biassed against him .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Christina , like the majority of her sex , has an unerring eye for the discreditable motive .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: She blames me because you wo n't help Henry . She thinks it 's because I 'm jealous of her .

lg.l: How exactly like her ! The best mother and the most unreasonable woman
I 've ever known .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Forcing the words out .It would be a great pleasure to me if you could change your mind and let Henry have the post instead of Ronald Parry .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , my dear , do n't ask me to do that . You know how I hate refusing to do anything you wish .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Anne is so anxious that Ronny should go to Paris . He 's made all his preparations , do n't you think you might just as well let him go ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm afraid I do n't . I want him here .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It would be such a joy to me if I could go and tell Christina that you 'd consented . It would make such a difference to me , you see . I want her to be fond of me , and I know she 'd never forget if I 'd been able to do her a good turn like that . Oh , Arthur , wo n't you ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Darling , I 'm afraid I can n't .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I promise I 'll never ask you anything again as long as I live if you 'll only do this for me . It means so much to me . You do n't know how much .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I can n't , Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Wo n't you talk it over with Anne ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: To tell you the truth I do n't think it 's any business of hers .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Hesitatingly .Is it due to her influence that Ronald was appointed to Paris ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I want to know . If she 's been pulling strings to get him moved I suppose it 's for some reason . He was very comfortable here . It 's not often you find a secretary who exactly suits you .

lg.l: Well , yes , it was her doing . She tells me she does n't mean to come to
Egypt so much as in the past and wants her brother nearer to her .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If she wants to see much of her brother she let him choose rather an unfortunate profession .... I wonder she did n't tell you the truth .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Quickly .I 'm convinced she did . I thought her explanation very natural . I 'm sorry it 's necessary for me to interfere with her plans .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm sure she would n't mind my telling you why she 's so anxious Ronny should leave Egypt . She thinks he 's in love with a married woman and it seems desirable to get him away . Perhaps she did n't want to tell you . I fancy she 's been very uneasy about it .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I daresay it 's only a momentary infatuation . Let us hope he will get over it quickly . I can n't lose a useful public servant because he happens to have formed an unfortunate attachment .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm afraid I 'm not explaining myself very well . Ronny is desperately in love . There 's no other way of putting it . You must let him go . After all , you 're very fond of him , you 've known him since he was a small boy ; it is n't as though he were a stray young man sent you by the Foreign Office . You can n't be entirely indifferent to him . Perhaps his welfare is at stake . Do n't you think it 's wiser — it 's only kind — to send him out of harm 's way .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , you know that I — Arthur Little — would do anything to please you and that I care very much for the happiness of Anne and the welfare of Ronald Parry . But , you see , I 'm an official too , and the official can n't do all sorts of things that the man would be very glad to .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How can you separate the official and the man ? The official can n't do things that the man disapproves .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Ah ! that 's a point that has been discussed ever since states came into being . Are the rules of private morality binding on the statesman ? In theory most of us answer yes , but in practice very few act on that principle . In this case , darling , it hardly applies . I see no conflict between the man and the official .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You think it does n't really concern you , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 've not said that . But I 'm not going to let an appeal to my emotions interfere with my judgment . I think I understand the situation . I 'm not proposing to change my mind . I shall present Ronny 's name to the Khedive to-morrow .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you think me very stupid , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Not at all , darling . Only a clever woman could achieve your beauty .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Then does n't it occur to you that if I 've made such a point of Ronny 's going it must be for some very good reason ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: With a quick look at her .Do n't you think we 'd better leave that subject alone , darling ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 'll think it silly and vain of me to say so , but I think you should know that — that Ronny 's in love with me . That is why I want him to go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's very natural that he should be in love with you . I 'm always surprised that everybody else is n't . I do n't see how I can prevent that except by taking you to live in the depths of the Sahara .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do n't make light of it , Arthur . It was n't very easy for me to tell you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: How do you wish me to take it ? I can n't blame Ronald . He 's by way of being a gentleman . I 've been good to him . He 'll make the best of a bad job .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you mean to say that it makes no difference to you ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: This secretaryship is a stepping-stone to a very important position . You 're not going to ask me to rob him of it because he 's done something so very natural as to fall in love with the most charming woman in Egypt ? I imagine that all my secretaries will fall in love with you . Poor devils , I do n't see how they can be expected to help it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You drive me mad . It 's so serious , it 's so tremendously serious , and you have the heart to make little jokes about it .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Gravely .Has it ever struck you that flippancy is often the best way of dealing with a serious situation ? Sometimes it 's really too serious to be taken seriously .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What do you mean by that ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Nothing very much . I was excusing myself for my ill-timed jests .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're determined to keep Ronny here ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Quite .There is a pause . ARTHUR gets up and puts his hand on her shoulder .I do n't think there 's anything more to say . If you will forgive me I will get back to the office .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , do n't go yet , Arthur . There 's something more I want to say to you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Will you allow me to advise you not to ? It 's so easy to say too much ; it 's never unwise to say too little . I beseech you not to say anything that we should both of us regret .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You think it 's unimportant if Ronny loves me , because you trust me implicitly .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Implicitly .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Has it never occurred to you that I might be influenced by his love against my will ? Do you think it 's so very safe ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If I allowed any doubt on that matter to enter my head I should surely be quite unworthy of your affection .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur , I do n't want to have any secrets from you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Trying to stop her .Do n't , Violet . I do n't want you to go on .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I must now .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , my dear , do n't you see that things said can never be taken back . We may both know something ....

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Interrupting .What do you mean ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: But so long as we do n't tell one another we can ignore it . If certain words pass our lips then the situation is entirely changed .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're frightening me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't wish to do that . Only you can tell me nothing that I do n't know . But if you tell me you may do irreparable harm .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you mean to say you know ? Oh , it 's impossible . Arthur , Arthur , I can n't help it . I must tell you . It burns my heart . I love Ronny with all my body and soul .

div.stage: There is a pause while they look at one another .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Did you think I did n't know ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Then why did you offer him the job ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I had to .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No one could have blamed you if you had suggested Henry .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , I 'm paid a very considerable salary . It would surely be taking money under false pretences if I did n't do my work to the best of my ability .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It may mean happiness or misery to all three of us .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I must take the risk of that . You see , Ronny is cut out for this particular position . It 's only common honesty to give it him .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do n't you love me any more ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do n't ask me that , Violet . You know I love you with all my heart .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Then I can n't understand .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You do n't think I want him to stay , do you ? When the telegram came from the Foreign Office ordering him to Paris my middle-aged heart simply leapt for joy . Do you think I did n't see all the advantages he had over me ? He seemed to have so much to offer you and I so little .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , Arthur !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: But if he went away I thought presently you 'd forget him . I thought if I were very kind to you and tolerant , and if I asked nothing more from you than you were prepared to give I might in time make you feel towards me , not love perhaps , but tenderness and affection . That was all I could hope for , but that would have made me very happy . Then the Khedive asked for an English secretary , and I knew Ronny was the only man for it . You see , I 've been at this work so long , the official in me makes decisions almost mechanically .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And supposing they break the heart of the man in you ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Smiling .By a merciful interposition of Providence we all seem to have just enough strength to bear the burdens that are placed on us .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you think so ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You like the rest of us , Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How long have you known I loved him ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Always . I think perhaps I knew before you did .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Why did n't you do something ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Will you tell me what there was to do ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Are n't you angry with us ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I should be a fool to be that . It seems to me so natural , so horribly natural . He 's young and nice-looking and cheery . It seems to me now inevitable that you should have fallen in love with him . You might be made for one another .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , do you see that ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It had struck you too , had it ? I suppose it 's obvious to anyone who takes the trouble to think about it .She does not answer .Have n't you wished with all your heart that you 'd met him first ? Do n't you hate me now because I married you ?She looks away .My dear child , I 'm so sorry for you . I 've been very grateful for your kindness to me during the last month or two . I 've seen you try to be loving to me and affectionate . I 've been so anxious to tell you not to force yourself , because I understood and you must n't be unhappy about me . But I did n't know how . I could only make myself as little troublesome as possible .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 've been immensely good to me , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That 's the least you had a right to expect of me . I did you a great wrong in marrying you . I knew you did n't love me . You were dazzled by the circumstances . You did n't know what marriage was and how irksome it must be unless love makes its constraints sweeter than freedom . But I adored you . I thought love would come . With all my heart I ask you to forgive me .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , Arthur , do n't talk like that . You know I was so happy to marry you . I thought you wonderful , I was so excited and flattered — I thought that was love . I never knew that love would come like this . If I 'd only known what to expect I could have fought against it . It took me unawares . I never had a chance . It was n't my fault , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm not blaming you , darling .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It would be easier for me if you did .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's just bad luck . Bad luck ? I might have expected it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Still , I 'm glad I 've told you . I hated having a secret from you . It 's better that we should be frank with one another .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: If I can help you in any way I 'm glad too that you 've told me .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What is to be done ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: There 's nothing to be done .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Arthur , until to-day Ronny and I have never exchanged a word that anyone might not have heard . I was happy to be with him , I knew he liked me , I was quite satisfied with that . But when I heard that he was going away suddenly everything was changed . I felt I could n't bear to let him go . Oh , I 'm so ashamed , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Dear child !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't know how it happened . He told me he loved me . He did n't mean to . Do n't think he 's been disloyal to you , Arthur . We were both so upset . It was just as much my fault as his . I could n't help letting him see how much he meant to me . We thought we were never going to see one another again . He took me in his arms and held me in them . I was so happy and so miserable . I never thought life could mean so much .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: And just now when you were alone he kissed your hands .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How do you know ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: When I wanted to kiss them you withdrew them . You could n't bear that I should touch them . You felt on them still the pressure of his lips .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I could n't help it . He was beside himself with joy because he need n't go . I do n't want to love him , Arthur . I want to love you . I 've tried so desperately hard .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , one either loves or one does n't . I 'm afraid trying does n't do much good .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If he stays here I shall have to see him constantly . I sha n't have a chance to get over it . Oh , I can n't . I can n't . It 's intolerable . Have pity on me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm afraid you 'll be very unhappy . But you see , something more than your happiness is at stake . A little while ago you said you wanted to do more for your country than you did . Does it strike you that you can do something for it now ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: We all want to do great and heroic things , but generally we can only do very modest ones . D'you think we ought to shirk them ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I do n't understand .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Ronny can be of infinite value here . You can n't help your feelings for him . I can n't bring myself to blame you . But you are mistress of your words and your actions . What are we to do ? You would n't wish me to resign when my work here is but half done . We must make the best of the position . Remember that all of us here , you more than most women , because you 're my wife , work for the common cause by our lives and the example we set . At all costs we must seem honest , straightforward , and without reproach . And one finds by experience that it 's much less trouble to be a thing than only to seem it . There 's only one way in which we can avoid reproach and that is by being irreproachable .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You mean that it 's necessary for the country that Ronny and you should stay here ? And if my heart breaks it does n't matter . I thought I was doing so much in asking you to send him away . Do n't you know that with all my heart I wanted him to stay ? D'you know what I feel , Arthur ? I can n't think of anything else . I 'm obsessed by a hungry longing for him . Till to-day I could have borne it . But now ... I feel his arms about me every moment , and his kisses on my lips . You can n't know the rapture and the torture and the ecstasy that consume me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , my dear , do you think I do n't know what love is ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I want to do the right thing , Arthur , but you must n't ask too much of me . If I 've got to treat him as a casual friend , I can n't go on seeing him . I can n't , Arthur , I can n't ! If he must stay then let me go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Never ! I think , even if it were n't necessary , I should make him stay now . You and I are not people to run away from danger . After all , we 're not obliged to yield to our passions — we can control them if we want to . For your own sake you must stay , Violet .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And if I break , I break .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's only the worthless who are broken by unhappiness . If you have faith and courage and honesty unhappiness can only make you stronger .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Have you thought of yourself , Arthur ? What will you feel when you see him with me ? What will you suspect when you 're working in your office and do n't know where I am ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I shall know that you are unhappy , and I shall feel the most tender compassion for you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're exposing me to a temptation that I want with all my heart to yield to . What is there to hold me back ? Only the thought that I must do my duty to you . What is there to reward me ? Only the idea that perhaps I 'm doing a little something for the country .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I put myself in your hands , Violet . I shall never suspect that you can do anything , not that I should reproach you for — I will never reproach you — but that you may reproach yourself for .

div.stage: A pause .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Just now , when we were talking of Abdul Said , I asked if you could do your duty when it was a matter that affected you , if it meant misery or happiness to you , I said .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , duty is rather a forbidding word . Let us say that I — want to earn my screw .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You must have thought me very silly . I said I hoped you 'd never be put to the test , and the test had come already , and you never hesitated .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: These things are very much a matter of habit , you know .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What you can do I can do too , Arthur — if you believe in me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Of course I believe in you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Then let him stay . I 'll do what I can .

div.stage: RONNY comes in .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: The Khedive was engaged when I rang up . But I left the message and the answer has just come through . He will be pleased to see you , sir , at eleven o'clock .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That will do admirably . Ronny must lunch with us to-morrow , Violet . We 'll crack a bottle to celebrate his step ! END OF THE SECOND ACT

div.head: ACT III

stage.stage: The scene shows part of the garden and a verandah at the Consular Agent 's house . Coloured lanterns are fixed here and there . It is night , and in the distance is seen the blue sky bespangled with stars . At the lack of the verandah are the windows of the house gaily lit . Within a band is heard playing dance-music . VIOLET is giving a dance . Everyone who appears is magnificently gowned . VIOLET is wearing all her pearls and diamonds . ARTHUR has across his shirt front the broad riband of an order . It is the end of the evening . Various people are sealed on the verandah , enjoying the coolness . They are MR. and MRS. APPLEBY , CHRISTINA and ARTHUR .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Well , my dear , I think it 's about time I was taking you back to your hotel .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , nonsense ! It 's when everybody has gone that a dance really begins to get amusing .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: That 's a pleasant remark to make to your guests .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm really ashamed to have stayed like this to the bitter end , but I do love to see the young folk enjoying themselves .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Ah ! you have learnt how to make the most of advancing years . The solace of old age is to take pleasure in the youth of those who come after us .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't think you 're very polite , Arthur .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Bless your heart , I know I 'm not so young as I was .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do you mind ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Me ? Why should I ? I 've had my day and I 've enjoyed it . It 's only fair to give others a chance now .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I 'm sure you enjoyed your trip up the Nile .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , we had a wonderful time .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: And what conclusions did you come to , Mr. Appleby ? I remember that you were looking for instruction as well as amusement .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I did n't forget what you told me . I just kept my ears open and my mouth shut .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: A capital practice , not much favoured by democratic communities .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: But I came to one very definite conclusion for all that .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: What was it ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: In fact , I came to two .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That 's not so satisfactory — unless they contradicted one another ; in which case I venture to suggest that you have grasped at all events the elements of the Egyptian problem .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: The first is that you 're the right man in the right place .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Christina would never admit that . She has known for many years that she could manage Egypt far better than I do .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't deny that for a minute . I think on the whole women are more level-headed than men . They 're not swayed by emotion . They 're more practical . They know that principle must often yield to expediency , and they can do the expedient without surrendering the principle .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You make my head whirl , Christina .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I had the opportunity of seeing a good many different sorts of people . I never heard a reasonable complaint against you . Some of them did n't like you personally , but they looked up to you , and they believed in you . I asked myself how you managed it .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I told him that it 's because you 're human .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Christina thinks it very bad for me to hear pleasant things said of me .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Christina does n't know what her brother would do if he had n't got an affectionate sister to gibe at .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: It must be a great satisfaction to you to see the country becoming every year more prosperous and contented .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: What was the second conclusion you came to ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm coming to that . Most of us are torn asunder as it were by a conflict of duties . This and that urgently needs to be done , and if you put one thing right you put something else wrong . We all want to do for the best , but we do n't exactly know what the best is . Now , you 've got your duty clearly marked out before you , if you take my meaning ; you 're young .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Youngish .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: You 've made a success of your job and of your life . It 's not all of us who can say that . My second conclusion is that you must be the happiest man alive .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I 'm glad he 's got that off his chest . He 's been dinning it into my ears for the last ten days . My impression is that he fell in love with Lady Little that day he lunched here six weeks ago .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm not going to blame him for that . Everybody does .... It was a wise old fellow who said that you must count no man happy till he 's dead .CHRISTINA gives him a look , and puts her hand affectionately on his arm . He quickly withdraws it .Here is Violet .

div.stage: She comes in on HENRY PRITCHARD 'S arm and sinks into a chair .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm absolutely exhausted . I feel that in another minute my legs will drop off .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do take care , darling , that would be so disfiguring .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , I 'd still dance on the stumps .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: When are you going to send that unfortunate band away ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , we must have one more dance . After all , it 's our last ball of the season . And now that everyone has gone I need n't be dignified any more . There 's no one but Henry and Anne and Ronny . We 've just had a gorgeous one-step , have n't we , Henry ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Gorgeous . You 're a ripping dancer .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: My one accomplishment .The band is heard beginning a waltz .Good heavens , they 've started again . That 's Anne , I 'm positive . She 's been playing the British matron too and now she 's having her fling .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You girls , you never grow up .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Are you ready for another turn , Violet ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do n't dance any more , darling , you look worn out .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Supposing you danced with your mother , Henry . I can see her toes itching inside her black satin slippers .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Nonsense ! I have n't danced for fifteen years .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Come on , mother . Just to show them you know how .

div.stage: He seizes her hand and drags her to her feet .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I was just as good a dancer as anybody else in my day .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: When Christina says that she means she was a great deal better .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Come on , mother , or it 'll be over before we begin .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't be rough with me , Henry .

div.stage: They go into the house .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: We rather fancied ourselves too , Fanny , once upon a time . What d'you say to trying what we can do , my dear ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: You be quiet , George . Fancy me dancing with my figure !

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I do n't deny you 're plump , but I never did like a scrag . Perhaps it 's the last chance we shall ever have .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: What would they say at home if they ever come to hear you and me had been dancing ? Really , George , I 'm surprised at you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Amused .I wo n't tell .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: You know you want to , Fanny . You 're only afraid they 'll laugh . Come on , or else I shall dance by myself .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Getting up .I see you 've quite made up your mind to make a fool of yourself .

div.stage: They go out . ARTHUR watches them , smiling .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: What good people ! It 's really a treat to see them together .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Mr. Appleby is very enthusiastic about you . He was telling me just now about his trip in Upper Egypt . He 's tremendously impressed . He said I ought to be very proud of you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I can n't imagine any remark more calculated to make you dislike me .

div.stage: She gives him a long look and then glances away . When she speaks it is with embarrassment .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Are you satisfied with me , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear , what do you mean ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Since that afternoon when I told you ....

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Yes , I know .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: We 've never talked about it .Giving him her hand .I want to thank you for having been so good to me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'm afraid you have n't got much to thank me for . It would have been easier if I 'd been able to help you , but I did n't see anything I could do but just sit still and twiddle my thumbs .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 've felt your confidence in me and that has been a help . You 've never given the slightest sign that anything was changed . You used sometimes to ask me what I 'd been doing during the day . Of late you have n't even done that .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I did n't want you to suspect for a moment that your actions were not perfectly free .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I know . No one could have been more considerate than you 've been . Oh , I 've been so unhappy , Arthur . I would n't go through the last six weeks for anything in the world .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It 's torn my heart to see you so pale and wan . And when , often , I saw you 'd been crying I almost lost my head . I did n't know what to do .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I could n't help it if I loved him , Arthur . That was n't in my power . But all that was in my power I 've done . Somehow I 've managed not to be alone with him .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Have n't you had any explanation with him ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: There did n't seem to be anything to explain . D'you think I ought to have told him I did n't love him ? I could n't , Arthur . I could n't .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear ! My dear !

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Once or twice he wrote to me . I knew he would and I 'd made up my mind not to read the letters . But when they came I could n't help myself . I had to read them . I was so wretched and it meant so much to me that he loved me .ARTHUR makes an instinctive movement of pain .I did n't mean to say that . Please forgive me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I think I understand .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I did n't answer them .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Did he only write once or twice ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: That 's all . You see , he can n't make it out . He thinks I 've treated him badly . Oh , I think that 's the hardest thing of all . I 've seen the misery in his eyes . And there was nothing I could do . I had n't the courage to tell him . I 'm weak . I 'm so horribly weak . And when I 'm with him alone I .... Oh , it is cruel that I should make him suffer so when he loves me .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't know what to say to you . It seems cold comfort to say that you must set your hope in the merciful effects of time . Time will ease your pain and his . Perhaps the worst is over already .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I hope with all my heart it is . I could n't have borne any more , Arthur . I 'm at the end of my strength .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Dear heart , you 're tired physically now . We 'll send these people away and you must go to bed .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Yes . I 'm exhausted . But I want to tell you , Arthur , I think you 're right . The worst is over . I 'm not suffering quite so much as I did . I find it a little easier not to think of him . When I meet him I can manage to be gay and flippant and indifferent . I 'm so glad , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You 've been very brave . I told you we were all strong enough to bear the burdens that are laid upon us .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You must n't think too well of me . I could n't have done what I have except for the consciousness of his great love for me . Is that awfully disloyal of me , Arthur ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Gravely .No , darling .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You can understand , can n't you ? It means so much to me . It 's helped me more than anything else in the world . It 's the only thing that made these past weeks not intolerable . I 'm satisfied to know he loves me . I want nothing more .

div.stage: MR. and MRS. APPLEBY come in . ARTHUR immediately assumes a chaffing manner .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Why , what 's this ? You have n't given in already ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: The spirit is willing enough , but the flesh is weak .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: We would n't like it talked about at home , but the fact is we got a bit out of breath .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Well , sit down a moment and rest yourself .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Just a moment if you do n't mind , and then we 'll be going .

div.stage: CHRISTINA appears with HENRY .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Here is poor Christina in a state of complete mental and physical collapse .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Do n't be ridiculous , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: How did you get on ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: First rate . Only mother wo n't let herself go . I kept on telling her there 's only one thing to do in modern dancing — let all your bones go loose and leave the man to do the rest .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: With a chuckle .I think modern dancing is an abandoned pastime . Nothing will induce me to let all my bones go loose .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Mother 's idea of dancing is to keep herself to herself .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Looking at him affectionately .You 're an impudent boy .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: To VIOLET .I do wish I 'd seen you dancing with Mr. Parry . He 's a wonderful dancer .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: He does dance well , does n't he ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Have n't you danced with him to-night , Violet ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No . He came rather late and my card was filled up . I promised him an extra , but some stuffy old diplomatist came and asked me for a dance , so I gave him Ronny 's .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: It 's too bad . It must be a rare sight to see you and Mr. Parry waltzing together .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How do you know he dances so well ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: There were two or three dances at our hotel last week and we saw him then .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh , I see .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: With a chuckle .I like that young man . When he gets hold of a good thing he freezes on to it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: There 's a young American girl staying at the hotel . She 's a Miss Pender . I wonder if you know her ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: No , I do n't think so . We get to know very few of the winter visitors .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: She 's a perfect picture to look at . And a beautiful dancer .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Everyone was looking at them last night . They made a wonderful pair .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do you know this lady , Henry ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Yes , I 've met her two or three times . She 's very pretty .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I do n't think anyone else had much of a look in with her .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Well , you need n't be disagreeable about it .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: As far as I could see she danced with Mr. Parry pretty well all the time .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: It was a treat to see them together .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: A little uncertainly .If one gets hold of a partner who suits one I always think it 's better to stick to him .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't think it was only that . She 's so much in love with him that she can n't help showing it .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I never saw such a fellow as Ronny . When there is a bit of luck going he always gets it .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: And is he in love with her too ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Oh , one can n't tell that .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: If he is n't he very soon will be . She 's too pretty for any man to resist long .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Lightly .You know them , the brutes , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Bless their hearts , I do n't blame them . What are pretty girls for except to make nice men happy ? I was a pretty girl myself once .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: And was Mr. Appleby a nice man ?

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: I think I must have been , for you 've certainly made me happy , my dear .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: I wish you 'd put that in writing , George . I 'd like to have a little something like that by me when you 've got a bit of a chill on your liver .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: H 'm , I think bed 's the place for you , Fanny . Say good-night to her ladyship and let 's be going .

sp.speaker: MRS. APPLEBY
sp.p: Good-night , Lady Little , and thank you so much for asking us . We have enjoyed ourselves .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: APPLEBY
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I hope you 'll have a pleasant journey home . Lucky people , you 'll see the spring in England . When you get back the hedgerows will be just bursting into leaf .

div.stage: The APPLEBYS go out .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How old is this American girl , Henry ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know , about nineteen or twenty .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is she as pretty as they say ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Rather .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is she fair ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Very . She 's got wonderful hair .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 've never mentioned her . Do you think Ronny is in love with her ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Oh , I do n't know about that . She 's great fun . And you know , it 's always flattering when a pretty girl makes a dead set at you .

div.stage: There is a momentary silence . VIOLET is extremely disturbed by the news that has just reached her . ARTHUR realises that a crisis has come .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: In a matter-of-fact way .Let us hope that something will come of it . There 's no reason why Ronny should n't marry . I think men marry much too late nowadays .

div.stage: ANNE and RONNY appear .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'm absolutely ashamed of myself . I half expected to find you 'd all gone to bed .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Smiling .Have you been having a jolly dance ?

lg.l: Think of having a good band and the whole floor to oneself . By the way ,
Violet , the band want to know if they can go away .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm sorry I had to cut your dance , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It was rotten luck . But I suppose on these occasions small fry like me have to put up with that sort of thing .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: If you like we 'll have a turn now before we send the band away .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'd love it .

div.stage: ARTHUR gives a little start and looks at VIOLET curiously . ANNE is surprised too .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: If you 're going to start dancing again we 'll go . Henry has to be at his office early in the morning .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Good-night , then .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Kissing her .Your dance has been a great success .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's nice of you to say so .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: To ARTHUR .Good-night , dear old thing . God bless and guard you always .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear Christina , why this embarrassing emotion ?

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: I do n't know what we should do if anything happened to you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do n't be an idiot , my dear ; nothing is going to happen to me .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: With a smile .I can n't get you out of thinking me a perfect fool .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Be off with you , Christina . If you go on finding out things that are not your business I shall have you deported .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What has she found out now ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: A trifle that we thought it would n't hurt the public to know nothing about .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Shaking hands with RONNY .I do n't grudge you your job any more . We 're all under a debt of gratitude to you .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I had a bit of luck , that 's all . It 's nothing to make a fuss about .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Go and have your dance , darling . It 's really getting very late .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: To RONNY .Are you ready ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: What shall we make them play ?

div.stage: They go out .

sp.speaker: CHRISTINA
sp.p: Good-night , ANNE .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Kissing her .Good-night , my dear .Henry shakes hands with ANNE and ARTHUR . He and his mother go out .I suppose I may n't ask what Christina was referring to ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I can n't prevent you from asking .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: But you have no intention of answering . What is the matter , Arthur ? You look so deadly white .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Nothing . I 'm tired . I had a busy day and now the dance .The sound of a waltz is heard .Oh , damn that music !

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Sit down and rest yourself . Why do n't you have a smoke !Putting her hand on his arm .My dear friend .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: For God 's sake do n't pity me .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Wo n't you talk to me frankly ? I may be able to help you . In the old days you used to bring your troubles to me , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I tell you I 'm only tired . What is the use of talking about what can n't be helped ?

lg.l: You must know that I notice most things that concern your happiness .
Why did you imagine I took so much trouble to get
Ronny moved to Paris ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I suspected . Ought I to thank you ? I 'm too miserable and too humiliated .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Have you heard about a Miss Pender ? She 's an American girl .

lg.l: Of course I have . It 's my business to know everything that goes on in
Cairo .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Do n't you think that may be the solution ?

div.stage: HENRY comes in .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Sharply .What d'you want ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I beg your pardon . Mother left her fan here .

div.stage: He takes it up from a chair .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I thought you 'd gone five minutes ago .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Oh , we just stood for a moment to look at Ronny and Violet dancing . Upon my soul it 's a fair treat .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: They make a wonderful couple , do n't they ?

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: I 'm afraid Violet 's awfully tired . She 's not saying a word and she 's as white as a sheet .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I 'll send her to bed as soon as they 've finished .

sp.speaker: HENRY
sp.p: Good-night .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Smiling .Good-night , my boy .

div.stage: Exit HENRY .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Is anything the matter ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Tell me about this American girl . She 's in love with Ronny , is n't she ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Yes , that 's obvious .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: And he ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: He 's been very unhappy , you know .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Almost savagely .That is a calamity which I find myself able to bear with patience .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: And now he 's surprised and pleased . I 've met her . Poor dear , she did everything to make me like her , because Ronny was my brother . She 's awfully pretty . He 's not in love with her yet . But I think he may be . He 's on the brink and if there were nothing else he 'd fall over .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That is what I suspected . You know , Anne , the longer I live the more inexplicable I find human beings . I always thought I was by way of being a fairly decent fellow . I never knew what mean beastliness there was inside me . It would be quite impossible for me to tell you how I hate your brother . I 've had to be jolly and affable with him and , by George , I wanted to kill him .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why did n't you let him go ? Are you sure it was necessary to give him that job ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Already he 's been invaluable .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Then one can only hope for the best .

div.stage: There is a moment 's pause . When ARTHUR speaks it is at first rather to himself than to ANNE .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No one knows what I 've gone through during the last few months . I 've been devoured with jealousy and I knew it would be fatal if I showed Violet the least trace of ill-temper . I kept on saying to myself that it was n't her fault if she was in love with Ronny .Humorously .You can n't think how devilish hard it is not to resent the fact that somebody does n't care for you .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With a chuckle .Oh yes , I can .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I knew that almost everything depended on how I acted during these weeks , and the maddening thing was that I could do nothing but sit still and control myself . I saw her miserable and knew that she did n't want my comfort . I 've yearned to take her in my arms and I 've known she 'd let me because it was her duty . Those dear good donkeys , the Applebys , told me just now they thought I must be the happiest man alive ! Week after week , with an aching heart I 've forced myself to be gay and amusing . D'you think I 'm amusing , Anne ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Sometimes .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The battle has been so unfair . All the dice are loaded against me . He has every advantage over me . But at last I thought I 'd won . I thought Violet was getting more resigned . She told me herself just now that the worst was over . And those confounded people must go and upset the applecart . Damn their eyes !

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The Applebys told her about Miss Pender . It was very natural . They knew no reason for not repeating the hotel gossip .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Was that why she asked Ronny to dance with her ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Yes . It 's the crisis . She had the strength to keep him at arm 's length when she knew he loved her . What will she do now ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You heard what Henry said . They do n't seem to be talking to one another .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why did you let them dance together ? You might easily have said it was too late and the band must go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: What good would that do ? No . I 've done nothing to prevent their meeting . I 've left them absolute liberty .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Do you think it 's fair to Violet ? You know , women act so much on impulse . The surroundings and the circumstances have so much influence on them . Think of the excitement of dancing , the magic of this wonderful night , and the solitude under these stars . You complain the dice are loaded against you , but now you 're double-loading them against yourself .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: It tortures me , but I must give them the opportunity to fight the matter out for themselves .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Poor child , she 's so young .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Too young .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Do n't say that ; it sounds as though you regretted having married her .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Do n't you imagine that regret has been tormenting her ever since she found out what love really was ? Even though I love her with all my heart I know now that I made a mistake . Do you think you can make anyone love you by constant tenderness , devotion , and kindness ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Not a man perhaps . But a woman yes , yes , yes !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Whoever loved that loved not at first sight ? I want so tremendously to make her happy , and I 've only made her utterly miserable . And there 's no way out . It 's a pity that a convenient attack of brain fever can n't carry me off , but I 'm as strong as a horse .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: You know , Arthur , there 's one compensation about the pains of love . While one 's suffering from them one feels one will never get over them , but one does , and when they 're gone they do n't even leave a scar . One looks back and remembers one 's torment and marvels that it was possible to suffer like that .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You talk as though you 'd had experience .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I have .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I always look upon you as so calm and self-controlled .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I was desperately in love for years with a man . I should have made him an excellent wife , although it 's I as says it . But it never occurred to him for an instant that my feelings were more than friendly . And eventually he married somebody else .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: My dear friend , I hate to think of your being unhappy .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'm not . That 's why I told you the tragic story . I 've got over it so completely that now I have an equal affection both for him and his wife .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: D'you know , Anne , at one time I very nearly asked you to marry me ?

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Gaily .Oh , what nonsense !

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I daresay it 's as well I did n't . I should have lost the best friend I 've ever had .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: On the other hand , I 've lost the satisfaction of refusing the most distinguished man of our day . Why did n't you ask me ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You were such an awfully good friend . I thought we were very well as we were .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: That is n't the reason , Arthur . You did n't ask me because you did n't love me . If you had you 'd have let friendship go hang .Seeing that he is not paying any attention to her .What 's the matter ?

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: The music has stopped .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With a slight tightening of the lips .I 'm afraid my concerns do n't interest you very much . I was only talking about them to distract you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Forgive me , but I 've got this anguish gnawing at my heart . Anne , when they come back here I want you to come with me for a stroll in the garden .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Why ? I 'm frightfully tired . I think I shall go to bed .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: No , do this for me , Anne . I want to give them their chance . It may be the last chance for all of us .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: With a little sigh .Very well , I 'll do even that for you .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: You are a good friend , and I 'm a selfish beast .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I wish you could have a child , Arthur . That might settle everything .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: That is what I look forward to with all my heart . I think she might love her baby 's father .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Then she 'll realise that only you could have been so tolerant and so immensely patient . When she looks back she 'll be filled with gratitude .

div.stage: RONNY and VIOLET come in .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 've told the band they can go .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: I do n't suppose they wanted telling twice . Did you have a pleasant dance ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I was very tired .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: It was brutal of me to make you dance so long . I 'll say good-night before I 'm turned out .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Oh , wo n't you sit down and have a cigarette before you go ? Anne and I were just going to stroll to the end of the garden to have a look at the Nile .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Oh .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: I 'm too restless to go to bed just yet .

div.stage: ARTHUR and ANNE go out . VIOLET and RONNY do not speak for a moment . At first the conversation is quite light .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: What was it that Christina was referring to just now ? Had it anything to do with you ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I do n't think I 'm justified in telling you about it . If Sir Arthur thinks you should know I daresay he 'd rather tell you himself .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Of course you must n't tell me if it 's a secret .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'd almost forgotten what a beautiful dancer you were .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: With a smile .So soon ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You have n't given me much chance of dancing with you during the last few weeks .

lg.l: I hear there 's a girl at the Ghezireh Palace who dances very well . Miss
Pender , is n't that her name ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Yes , she 's wonderful .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm told she 's charming .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Very .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I should like to meet her . I wonder whom I know that could bring us together .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: With a change of tone .Why do you speak of her ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Is there any reason why I should n't ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Do you know that this is the first time I 've been quite alone with you for six weeks ?

lg.l: It was inevitable that when you ceased being
Arthur 's private secretary we should see less of one another .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I only welcomed my new job because I thought I should n't be utterly parted from you .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do n't you think it was better that we should n't see too much of one another ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: What have I done to you , Violet ? Why have you been treating me like this ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'm not conscious that I 've treated you differently from what I used .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Why did n't you answer my letters ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: In a low voice .I had n't anything to say .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I wonder if you can imagine what I went through , the eagerness with which I looked forward to a letter from you , just a word or two would have satisfied me , how anxiously I expected each post , and my despair when day after day went by .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You ought not to have written to me .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: D'you think I could help myself ? Have you forgotten that day when we thought we were never going to meet again ? If you wanted me to be nothing more than a friend why did you tell me you loved me ? Why did you let me kiss you and hold you in my arms ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You know quite well . I lost my head . I was foolish . You — you attached too much importance to the emotion of the moment .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , Violet , how can you say that ? I know you loved me then . After all , the past can n't be undone . I loved you . I know you loved me . We could n't go back to the time when we were no more than friends .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You forget that Arthur is my husband and you owe him everything in the world . We both owe him everything in the world .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: No , I do n't forget it for a moment . After all , we 're straight , both of us , and we could have trusted ourselves . I wanted nothing but to be allowed to love you and to know that you loved me .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do you remember what you said in the first letter you wrote me ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , you can n't blame me for that . I 'd loved you so long , so passionately . I 'd never dared to hope that you cared for me . And when I knew ! I never said a tenth part of what I wanted to . I went home and I just wrote all that had filled my heart to overflowing . I wanted you to know how humbly grateful I was for the wonderful happiness you 'd given me . I wanted you to know that my soul to its most hidden corners was yours for ever .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: How could I answer it ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: You need n't have been afraid of me , Violet . If it displeased you I would never even have told you that I loved you . I would have carried you in my heart like an image of the Blessed Virgin . When we met here or there , though there were a thousand people between us and we never exchanged a word , I should have known that we were the only people in the world , and that somehow , in some strange mystic fashion , I belonged to you and you belonged to me . Oh , Violet , I only wanted a little kindness . Was it so much to ask ?

div.stage: VIOLET is moved to the very depths of her heart . She can scarcely control herself , the pain she suffers seems unendurable ; her throat is so dry that she can hardly speak .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: They say that Miss Pender is in love with you . Is it true ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: A man 's generally a conceited ass when he thinks girls are in love with him .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Never mind that . Is it true ? Please be frank with me .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Perhaps it is .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Would she marry you if you asked her ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I think so .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: She can n't have fallen in love with you without some encouragement .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: She plays tennis a good deal and she 's very fond of dancing . You know , I was rather wretched . Sometimes you looked at me as though you hated me . You seemed to try and avoid me . I wanted to forget . I did n't know what I 'd done to make you treat me so cruelly . It was very pleasant to be with someone who seemed to want me . Everything I did pleased her . She 's rather like you . When I was with her I was a little less unhappy . When I found she was in love with me I was touched and I was tremendously grateful .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Are you sure you 're not in love with her ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Yes , I 'm quite sure .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: But you like her very much , do n't you ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Yes , very much .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Do n't you think if it were n't for me you would be in love with her ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I do n't know .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I 'd like you to be frank with me .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Unwillingly .You do n't want my love . She 's sweet and kind and tender .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: I think she might make you very happy .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Who knows ?

div.stage: There is a pause . VIOLET forces herself to make the final renunciation . Her fingers move spasmodically in the effort she makes to speak calmly .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It seems a pity that you should waste your life for nothing . I 'm afraid you 'll think me a heartless flirt . I 'm not that . At the time I feel all I say . But ... I do n't quite understand myself . I take a violent fancy to someone , and I lose my head , but somehow it does n't last . I ... I suppose I 'm not capable of any enduring passion . There are people like that , are n't there ? It goes just as suddenly as it comes . And when it goes — well , it 's gone for ever . I can n't understand then what on earth I saw in the man who made my heart go pit-a-pat . I 'm dreadfully sorry I caused you so much pain . You took it so much more seriously than I expected . And afterwards I did n't know what to do . You must — you must try to forgive me .

div.stage: There is a long pause .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Do n't you love me at all now ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: It 's much better that I should tell you the truth , is n't it ? even at the risk of hurting your feelings . I 'm frightfully ashamed of myself . I 'm afraid you 'll think me awfully frivolous .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Why do n't you say it right out ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: D'you want me to ?She hesitates , but then takes courage .I 'm very sorry , dear Ronny , I 'm afraid I do n't care for you in that way at all .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: I 'm glad to know .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: You 're not angry with me ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Oh , no , my dear , how can you help it ? We 're made as we 're made .... D'you mind if I go now ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Wo n't you stop and say good-night to Anne ?

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: No , if you do n't mind , I 'd like to go quickly .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Very well . And try to forgive me , Ronny .

sp.speaker: RONNY
sp.p: Good-night .

div.stage: He takes her hand and they look into one another 's eyes .

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: Good-night .

div.stage: He goes out . VIOLET clasps her hands to her heart as though to ease its aching . ANNE and ARTHUR return .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Where is Ronny ?

sp.speaker: VIOLET
sp.p: He 's gone . It was so late . He asked me to say good-night to you .

sp.speaker: ANNE
sp.p: Thank you . It must be very late . I 'll say good-night too .She bends down and kisses VIOLET .Good-night , Arthur .

sp.speaker: ARTHUR
sp.p: Good-night .She goes out . ARTHUR sits down . A SAIS comes in and turns out some of the lights . In the distance is heard the wailing of an Arab song . ARTHUR motions to the SAIS .Leave these .
